{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Gerald Majera Ssendaula | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1943|05|15}} | birth_place = [[Uganda]] | death_date = | death_place = | alma_mater = [[Nairobi University]]
{{small|([[Bachelor of Commerce|BCom]])}} | occupation = Farmer and politician | years_active = 1980 – present | nationality = Ugandan | citizenship = [[Uganda]] | residence = [[Masaka]], Uganda | networth = | home_town = [[Masaka]] | title = [[Chairman]]
[[Tropical Bank]]
[[Uganda Revenue Authority]]{{cite web|accessdate=7 February 2015 |newspaper=[[New Vision|New Vision Mobile]] (Kampala) |url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/mobile/Detail.aspx?NewsID=659297&CatID=1 |date=2014 |first=David |last=Lumu |title=Kagina’s Job: URA Board Speaks Out |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150207235320/http://www.newvision.co.ug/mobile/Detail.aspx?NewsID=659297&CatID=1 |archivedate=7 February 2015 |df=dmy }}
Private Sector Foundation
''NUCAFE''{{cite web|accessdate=7 December 2015| url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/news/650111-coffee-farmers-win-continental-award.html|title=Coffee Farmers Win Continental Award| date=3 December 2013|first=David|last=Ssempijja|newspaper=[[New Vision]] (Kampala)}} }} '''Gerald Majera Ssendaula''' is a retired Ugandan politician, and current banker and farmer. He is a former Cabinet Minister and MP Member of Parliament, representing Kingo sub-county, which became [[Lwengo District]]. ==Background and education== Ssendaula was born on 15 May 1943 in Kyabbogo Village, Kingo sub-county, in [[Masaka District]] at that time, to the late Edward Byansi Kalibbala and Maria Nakanwagi Nakato. He is the oldest amongst eight siblings; six brothers and two sisters. In 2010, Kingo sub-county was peeled off Masaka District to create [[Lwengo District]]. He started his education at Kyoko Primary School, and then transferred to Nkoni Primary School. He continued his studies at St. Pius Junior Secondary School. Because his father was less interested in educating children, Ssendaula's mother applied for a Buganda Government scholarship to take the young Ssendaula to a reasonable school but without success. He later met with Aga Ssekalala of Ugachick who was then a student of Senior Four but knew some [[Buganda Kingdom]] officials. Aga Ssekalala later introduced Ssendaula to the Mengo establishment, leading to the re-activation of his scholarship application in 1963. A scholarship of Shs905 then enabled him to join [[Namilyango College]], where he studied from Senior One to Senior Six. He later joined [[Nairobi University]] in 1969 where he graduated with the [[Bachelor of Commerce]] degree. There were about 30 other Ugandans at Nairobi University during his time, including Livingstone Okello Okello (Chua County), FDC's [[Cecilia Ogwal]] (Dokolo Woman MP), and [[Mondo Kagonyera|Professor Mondo Kagonyera]]. == Work experience == After his studies in [[Kenya]], Ssendaula returned to [[Barclays Bank (Uganda)|Barclays Bank]] in Uganda, where he had worked as a clerk during his S6 vacation. The two-year Barclays Bank London training known as 'Day Release' prepared him for an administrative role. He worked at the bank's [[Kabale]] branch before he was transferred to [[Nairobi]] to conduct some in-house training. He later returned to Uganda and rose to the rank of General Manager with Barclays Bank. He joined politics in 1980 and was elected MP for Bukoto, Masaka District, serving in that role until 1985, on the [[Democratic Party (Uganda)|Democratic Party]] ticket, until 1985. He was elected Chairman of Masaka District in 1988 and served as such until 1992. In 1992, he was elected as the National Resistance Council (the Parliament of that time), representative for Bukoto, Masaka. He also contemporaneously served as the Chairman of Masaka Growers Cooperative Union. == Political life == In 1980 Ssendaula joined politics as a Democratic Party (DP) supporter contesting for [[Parliament of Uganda|Parliament]] MP and got elected for Bukoto Central (presently Bukomansimbi and Masaka Municipality). With UPC in power and DP in opposition, Ssendaula was shadow spokesman for Housing, while Evaristo Nyanzi was for Finance. In 1982, Ssendula's wife, Rosemary Nanyonga Nalongo, was shot dead at their grocery in [[Mpererwe]], 5miles on Gayaza Road, opposite their home. It was 2 pm and Ssendaula was in Masaka working at his father's coffee farm in Kinoni. The crime of his wife was apparently opening her shop while Minister Samwiri Mugwisa was addressing a rally in [[Kawempe]], moreover speaking about rebel activities in the country. Mrs. Ssendaula tried to reason with the soldiers who attacked her, that Kawempe, where the rally was being held, was far away from Mpererwe where her shop was. They didn't listen, shooting her there and then. With the murder of his wife at the back of his mind, Ssendaula left his Mpererwe home joining the [[National Resistance Army]] when the rebels started capturing territory around 1984. It was Commander Victor Bwana, who persuaded him to join [[Museveni]]'s forces and he was too angry with the UPC government to resist the temptation. Ssendaula helped the rebels export coffee beans and hides to get some revenue since he was attached to the defunct Masaka Cooperative Union. At that time in 1984, the NRA had established a government in the captured territory as the Kampala – Masaka road was cut off by the rebels, with their headquarters in Fort Portal. Ssendaula served in this 'government' as a commissioner, the equivalent of a minister. When the NRA captured power, he worked briefly at the [[National Resistance Movement]] (NRM) Secretariat, basically to wind up the rebels' export business as there was now a government to take care of it. In 1987, he went to Masaka, contested and got elected district chairman as its first District chairman under the NRM. He later joined the expanded National Resistance Council (NRC) legislature in 1989 as Bukoto MP. In 1990, President Museveni appointed Ssendaula deputy minister of Commerce and Co-operatives under [[Richard Kaijuka]], another banker. In 1996, he was promoted full minister for Natural Resources.{{cite web|title=The Mineral Industry of Uganda| first=Philip|last=Mobbs|accessdate=7 February 2015|format=PDF| url=http://minerals.usgs.gov/minerals/pubs/country/1997/ug97.pdf| publisher=Minerals.usgs.gov}} At the beginning of 1998, Ssendaula became Minister of Finance, Planning and Economic Development, a position he held until his retirement in 2005. He joined politics representing the [[Democratic Party (Uganda)|Democratic Party]] where he was the Member of Parliament for Bukoto constituency then the largest constituency in Uganda from 1980 – 1985 which was split into, Bukoto Central, Bukoto South, Bukoto Mid West later remaining as the MP for Bukoto South in then Masaka District. He was elected on a Democratic Party ticket switching to the political setting, NRM – Movement. He continued to become a Cabinet Minister in the Museveni Government as the Deputy Minister of Commerce and Cooperatives, which Ministry was changed and Named Ministry of Trade and Industries from 1991– 1996. He rose to full Minister as the Minister of Natural Resources and Environment from 1996–1998, where he was transferred to The Ministry of Finance, Planning and Economic Development{{cite book |title=Making Public Enterprises Work: From Despair to Promise – A Turn Around Account |last=Muhairwe |first=William T. |page=278 |year=2009 |publisher=[[International Water Association]] |isbn=978-1-84339-324-5 }} as its head through 1998–2005, where he retired from active politics. ==Other considerations== {{asof|February 2015}}, he is a full-time farmer based in Masaka. He is also an Adviser to President Museveni on Financial Matters. He serves as a Consultant to the [[World Bank]]. He is the Chairman [[Uganda Revenue Authority]], Chairman Board of Directors [[Tropical Bank]], Director in [[Umeme]] Ltd{{cite web|url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/news/660268-ex-finance-minister-ssendaula-defends-nssf-umeme-deal.html|}} and NUCAFE.{{cite web|first=Stephen|last=Muneza| url=http://www.redpepper.co.ug/uganda-coffee-wins-africa-award/| title=Uganda Coffee Wins Africa Award|accessdate=7 February 2015| date=3 December 2015|newspaper=[[Red Pepper (newspaper)|Red Pepper]]}} He was married to Grace Tereza Nabatanzi Ssendawula, the daughter of [[Paul Ssemogerere|Paul Kawanga Ssemogerere]], the Ugandan Democratic Party politician. She died in 2011{{cite web| url=http://www.millerfuneral.com/obits/obituaries.php/obitID/592951| title=Grace Teresa Nabatanzi Ssendaula:26 May 1963 - 8 May 2011| publisher=Miller Funeral Services & Cremation Society of Texas, Houston Texas, United States (MFS&CST)|date=2011|accessdate=7 February 2015|first=.|last=MFS&CST}} == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/NSSF-was-not-forced-to-purchase-Umeme-shares--says-ex-minister/-/688334/2470546/-/wa7wg7z/-/index.html NSSF Was Not Forced To Purchase Umeme Shares, Says Ex-Minister] {{DEFAULTSORT:Ssendaula Gerald}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Ugandan politicians]] [[Category:1943 births]] [[Category:Ganda people]] [[Category:Ugandan Roman Catholics]] [[Category:People educated at Namilyango College]] [[Category:Ugandan bankers]] [[Category:University of Nairobi alumni]] [[Category:Members of the Parliament of Uganda]] [[Category:Government ministers of Uganda]]

{{Refimprove|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox character | colour = #DEDEE2 | colour text = | name = Ginés de Pasamonte | alias = Ginesillo de Parapilla | series = [[Don Quixote]] | image = | caption = | first = Part I, Chapter 22 (as prisoner) | last = Part II, Chapter 26 (as puppet master) | cause = | creator = [[Miguel de Cervantes]] | portrayer = | gender = Male | occupation = Thief, writer, puppet-showman | title = | family = | spouse = | children = | relatives = | religion = | nationality = [[Spain|Spanish]] }}
'''Ginés de Pasamonte''' is a fictional character in [[Miguel de Cervantes]]' novel ''[[Don Quixote]]''.
Ginés first appears as a criminal freed by Don Quixote in the 22nd chapter of the first part of the novel. After his release, he escapes Don Quixote and the guards. He later reappears as Maese Pedro, a puppet-showman who claims that he can talk to his monkey, on the 26th chapter of the second part.
He also stole Sancho's donkey, a part that was omitted from the first edition.
Prior to his release by Don Quixote, Ginés tells him that he is in the process of writing his own autobiography. Don Quixote interrogates this writer about his book; {{cquote|"Is it so good?" said Don Quixote.
"So good is it," replied Gines, "that a fig for 'Lazarillo de Tormes,' and all of that kind that have been written, or shall be written compared with it: all I will say about it is that it deals with facts, and facts so neat and diverting that no lies could match them."
"And how is the book entitled?" asked Don Quixote.
"The ''Life of Gines de Pasamonte''," replied the subject of it.
"And is it finished?" asked Don Quixote.
"How can it be finished," said the other, "when my life is not yet finished?|15px|15px|Literature Network: Miguel de Cervantes: ''Don Quixote''|<ref name="Don Quixote">{{cite web |url=http://www.online-literature.com/view.php/don_quixote/26?term=lazarillo |publisher= English Translation by John Ormsby, 1885 |title=Don Quixote, Chapter XXII|accessdate=30 July 2011}}</ref>}} This is the only reference to the popular novel ''[[Lazarillo de Tormes]]'' in the book, and it acts as an alterego for Don Quixote's will to be a literary hero in his own lifetime.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Don Quixote}}

{{Philippine name|Magno|Padaca}} {{Infobox Officeholder |name = Grace Padaca |image = |imagesize = |office = [[Isabela (province)|Governor of Isabela]] |term_start = June 30, 2004 |term_end = June 30, 2010 |predecessor = Faustino Dy Jr. |successor = Faustino G. Dy III |office2 = Commissioner of [[COMELEC|Commission on Elections]] |term_start2 = October 8, 2012 |term_end2 = June 30, 2014 |predecessor2 = Agusto Lagman |successor2 = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1963|10|25}} |birth_name = Maria Gracia Cielo Magno Padaca |birth_place = |death_date = |death_place = |alma_mater = [[Lyceum of the Philippines University]] |spouse = |party = [[Independent (politician)|Independent]] (2004-2009, 2014-present) |otherparty = [[Liberal Party (Philippines)|Liberal]] (2010-2014) }} '''Gracia Cielo "Grace" Magno Padaca''' (born October 25, 1963) is a Filipino politician and former broadcaster who has been the governor of the northern Luzon province of [[Isabela province|Isabela]], [[Philippines]] since 2004.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/inquirerheadlines/regions/view/20080806-152906/The-challenge-to-carve-a-Tatak-Isabelino |title=The challenge to carve a ‘Tatak Isabelino’ - INQUIRER.net, Philippine News for Filipinos |publisher=Newsinfo.inquirer.net |date= |accessdate=2012-10-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120607002258/http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/inquirerheadlines/regions/view/20080806-152906/The-challenge-to-carve-a-Tatak-Isabelino |archivedate=2012-06-07 |df= }}</ref> She is also the recipient of the Ramon Magsaysay Award for Public Service in 2008.
During her childhood, she survived [[polio]]; she has walked with [[crutch]]es for most of her life.
==Biography== Padaca ran for Congress in 2001 where she lost to Faustino "Bojie" Dy, by a margin of 1,285 votes (he got 50.7 percent of the vote to her 49.3 percent). She protested the results of 151 ballot boxes. Dy countered, questioning the results not only of the 151 precincts but all 812 precincts. Padaca initiated what she called an "Adopt A Ballot Box" campaign to raise funds to cover the cost of a ballot box revision. After two and a half years, the House of Representatives Electoral Tribunal (HRET), in a decision promulgated on December 18, 2003, declared Dy the winner by 48 votes. The majority of the HRET refused to count ballots with "Grace" written on them in favor of Grace Padaca.
Padaca won the [[Philippine general election, 2004|2004 gubernatorial election]] in the northern Luzon province of [[Isabela province|Isabela]] with 55% of the vote.
On December 5, 2007, [[United States]] Ambassador Kristie Kenney personally conferred to Padaca the International Women of Courage Award, an award which was also conferred to former U.S. Secretary of State [[Condoleezza Rice]]. It was bestowed on Padaca for her continued development of [[Isabela (province)|Isabela]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/storypage.aspx?StoryId=101285 |accessdate=July 2, 2008 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
Padaca, 44, on July 31, 2008 was among the eight winners of the 2008 [[Ramon Magsaysay Award]], for Government Service for "empowering Isabela voters to reclaim their democratic right to elect leaders of their own choosing, and to contribute as full partners in their own development."<ref name="abs-cbnnews1">[http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/storypage.aspx?StoryId=126931 ]{{dead link|date=October 2012}}</ref>
Padaca campaigned against [[illegal logging]] problems.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanews.tv/video/27703/iWitness-Si-GOB-at-ang-mga-BUGADOR |title=iWitness: Si GOB at ang mga BUGADOR | I-Witness | GMA News Online | The Go-To Site for Filipinos Everywhere |publisher=Gmanews.tv |date=2008-08-25 |accessdate=2012-10-02}}</ref> Padaca reactivated the anti-illegal task force.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanews.tv/story/114671/Isabela-gov-sees-big-job-ahead-vs-illegal-logging |title=Isabela gov sees big job ahead vs illegal logging | News | GMA News Online | The Go-To Site for Filipinos Everywhere |publisher=Gmanews.tv |date=2008-08-19 |accessdate=2012-10-02}}</ref>
Padaca, [[Eddie Panlilio]] (of Pampanga), [[Naga, Camarines Sur|Naga]] Mayor [[Jesse Robredo]], and Mayor Sonia Lorenzo of [[San Isidro, Northern Samar|San Isidro]], [[Nueva Ecija]], launched "Kaya Natin", a group that "seeks to recruit principled local government officials to change the country's deteriorating political situation." Their 'Islands of Hope' - university campus tour, a movement for ethical leadership and good governance was launched on July 31, 2008, at the [[Ateneo de Manila University]]'s Walter Hogan Conference Center in Quezon City.<ref name="abs-cbnnews1"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/inquirerheadlines/nation/view/20080731-151768/Islands-of-hope-to-go-on-campus-tour |title=‘Islands of hope’ to go on campus tour - INQUIRER.net, Philippine News for Filipinos |publisher=Newsinfo.inquirer.net |date=2008-07-31 |accessdate=2012-10-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120604000443/http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/inquirerheadlines/nation/view/20080731-151768/Islands-of-hope-to-go-on-campus-tour |archivedate=2012-06-04 |df= }}</ref>
In the 2010 election Padaca was defeated by three-term congressman Bojie Dy of the 3rd district of Isabela with a margin of 3,438 votes.<ref>{{cite web |author=Danny Fajardo |url=http://www.manilatimes.net/index.php/news/regions/17381-grace-padaca-loses-in-isabela-gubernatorial-race |title=One of the ‘ten wise men’ |publisher=Manilatimes.net |date=2012-02-17 |accessdate=2012-10-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120609145952/http://www.manilatimes.net/index.php/news/regions/17381-grace-padaca-loses-in-isabela-gubernatorial-race |archivedate=2012-06-09 |df= }}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} {{Use British English|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox MP | honorific-prefix = | name = Jared O'Mara | honorific-suffix = {{Post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100%|MP}} | image = Official portrait of Jared O'Mara crop 2.jpg | alt = | caption = Official Parliamentary portrait, June 2017 | office = [[Member of Parliament (United Kingdom)|Member of Parliament]]
for [[Sheffield Hallam (UK Parliament constituency)|Sheffield Hallam]] | parliament = | majority = 2,125 (3.8 %) | term_start = 8 June 2017 | term_end = | predecessor = [[Nick Clegg]] | successor = | birth_name = Jared Cain O'Mara | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1981|11|15|df=yes}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | citizenship = United Kingdom | nationality = British |party = [[Independent politician|Independent]] (2018-)
[[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] (until 2018) |otherparty = | spouse = | children = | parents = | residence = | education = | alma_mater = [[Staffordshire University]] | occupation = | profession = }} '''Jared Cain O'Mara''' (born 15 November 1981){{cite web|url=http://myparliament.info/Member/4661|title=Biography for Jared O'Mara|website=MyParliament}} is a [[United Kingdom|British]] politician. He has been the [[Member of parliament|Member of Parliament]] (MP){{cite web|url=http://www.parliament.uk/biographies/commons/jared-o'mara/4661|title=Jared O'Mara MP|website=UK Parliament|accessdate=23 October 2017}} for the constituency of [[Sheffield Hallam (UK Parliament constituency)|Sheffield Hallam]] since 8 June 2017, and was elected as the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] candidate.{{cite news|first=Henry |last=Bodkin |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/06/09/nick-clegg-loses-seat-amid-liberal-democrat-slump-sheffield/ |title=Nick Clegg 'loses seat' amid Liberal Democrat slump in Sheffield Hallam |work=The Telegraph |date= |accessdate=9 June 2017}} After joining Parliament, O'Mara became a member of the [[Women and Equalities Committee|Women and Equalities Select Committee]], but resigned in October 2017, following the publication of offensive comments about women and gay men that he had made in 2009 and earlier.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-41750136|title=Labour suspends MP Jared O'Mara after online comments|publisher=BBC News|date=25 October 2017|accessdate=25 October 2017}}{{cite news|last=Elgot|first=Jessica|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/oct/23/labour-mp-jared-omara-sheffield-hallam-sorry-girls-aloud-orgy|title=Labour MP quits equality committee over homophobic posts|work=The Guardian|date=23 October 2017|accessdate=23 October 2017}} O'Mara was suspended from the Labour Party on 25 October 2017, following further reports of online comments made before his election that have been described as racist,{{cite news|last=Buchan|first=Lizzie|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/jared-o-mara-latest-labour-party-suspend-whip-mp-verbal-abuse-girls-aloud-a8018891.html|title=Jared O'Mara: Labour MP suspended by party after series of offensive comments revealed|work=The Independent|date=25 October 2017|accessdate=1 April 2018}} homophobic and misogynistic. O'Mara was reinstated in the Labour Party in July 2018,{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/jul/03/labour-set-to-reinstate-suspended-mp-jared-omara|title=Labour reinstates suspended MP Jared O'Mara|last=Elgot|first=Jessica|date=3 July 2018|website=the Guardian|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=3 July 2018}} but resigned from the party nine days later. He now sits as an [[Independent politician|independent]] MP.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-south-yorkshire-44816015|title=Reinstated MP quits Labour Party|last=|first=|date=12 July 2018|work=BBC News|access-date=12 July 2018|language=en-GB}} == Early life and education == O'Mara was born in [[Sheffield]].{{Who's Who | surname = O’Mara| othernames = Jared| id = U289498| volume = 2018 | edition = February 2018 online | accessed = 14 February 2018 }} He has [[cerebral palsy]], [[hemiparesis]] and is on the [[autism spectrum]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sheffieldhallamlabour.org.uk/a_bit_about_me_jared_o_mara|title=A bit about me - Jared O'Mara|website=Sheffield Labour Party|accessdate=9 June 2017}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.itv.com/news/calendar/2018-07-10/sheffield-mp-jared-omara-reveals-he-tried-to-take-his-own-life-during-labour-party-suspension/|title=Sheffield Hallam MP Jared O'Mara reveals he tried to take his own life during Labour Party suspension|last=|first=|date=10 July 2018|work=ITV News|access-date=11 July 2018|language=en}} He was educated at [[Tapton School]], in the city's [[Crosspool]] suburb,{{cite book|author1=Tim Carr|author2=Iain Dale|author3=Robert Waller|authorlink2=Iain Dale|authorlink3=Robert Waller (pundit)|title=The Politicos Guide to the New House of Commons 2017}} and graduated from [[Staffordshire University]] with a [[first class honours degree]] in Journalism.{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/meet-disability-rights-campaigner-first-10594986|title=Meet MP Jared O'Mara who ousted Nick Clegg in shock election result|last=Howes|first=Scarlet|date=9 June 2017|work=The Mirror|accessdate=9 June 2017|archive-url=|archivedate=|dead-url=}} Before entering politics, he was a local school governor and had volunteered for Sheffield-based disability information services and charities. With friends, he ran West Street Live, a bar and music venue in Sheffield.{{cite news|last=Cooke|first=Rachel|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/jun/18/jared-omara-labour-mp-sheffield-hallam-defeated-nick-clegg|title=Jared O'Mara, the pub-owning first-time MP who won Nick Clegg's seat|work=The Observer|date=18 June 2017|accessdate=7 July 2017}} O'Mara had stood as a Labour candidate in various Sheffield council elections.{{cite web|url=http://mdfs.net/Docs/Sheffield/Election/2004/Votes.htm|title=2004 Sheffield Council election results|accessdate=10 June 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://mdfs.net/Docs/Sheffield/Election/2015/Votes.htm|title=2015 Sheffield Council election results|accessdate=10 June 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://mdfs.net/Docs/Sheffield/Election/2016/Votes.htm|title=2016 Sheffield Council election results|accessdate=10 June 2017}} He supported [[Jeremy Corbyn]]'s election as [[Leader of the Labour Party (UK)|Leader of the Labour Party]] in [[Labour Party (UK) leadership election, 2015|2015]] and [[Labour Party (UK) leadership election, 2016|2016]],{{Cite web|url=http://sybriefing.co.uk/2017/06/01/labours-hallam-candidate-says-liberal-democrats-nick-clegg-doesnt-care-sheffield/|title=Labour's Hallam candidate says Liberal Democrat's Nick Clegg doesn't care about Sheffield|last=Taylor|first=Harry|date=1 June 2017|website=South Yorkshire Briefing|archive-url=|archivedate=|dead-url=|accessdate=14 June 2017}} was a [[Momentum_(organisation)|Momentum]] supporter and was backed by them during the 2017 election.{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171025160145/http://www.momentumsheffield.org/?p=850|title=Momentum Sheffield {{!}} Campaign Training Session: Sunday 14th May – Crookes|date=25 October 2017|accessdate=26 December 2017}} == Parliamentary career == In the [[United Kingdom general election, 2017|2017 general election]], O'Mara contested the constituency of Sheffield Hallam, held by [[Nick Clegg]], the former [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrat]] leader and former [[Deputy Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Deputy Prime Minister]].{{cite news|first=Alex |last=Moore |url=http://www.thestar.co.uk/news/labour-selects-jared-o-mara-to-challenge-nick-clegg-in-sheffield-1-8522836 |title=Labour selects Jared O'Mara to challenge Nick Clegg in Sheffield |work=The Star |location=Sheffield |date=2 May 2017 |accessdate=9 June 2017}} He was selected in an emergency selection process for the snap election under the control of the [[National Executive Committee]] and regional boards, rather than by the local constituency party.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-39658426 |title=General election 2017: Can parties select candidates in time? |work=BBC News |date=22 April 2017 |accessdate=27 October 2017}} His campaign benefited from a national surge in the Labour vote and from university students in the constituency.{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/06/09/first-time-mp-beat-nick-clegg-bought-new-suit-tesco-shock-result/|title=First-time MP who beat Nick Clegg 'bought a new suit from Tesco' as shock result emerged|last=Horton|first=Helena|date=9 June 2017|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=11 June 2017|archive-url=|archivedate=|dead-url=}} It has been claimed that Clegg was thought to be too anti-[[Brexit]] by voters, although Sheffield Hallam was estimated to have voted Remain in the [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016|2016 European Union Referendum]], and O'Mara supports Remain as well. O'Mara's campaign focused on disabled people's rights, protecting public services and on his personal background in Sheffield. He won the seat with a majority of 2,125 votes, overturning Clegg's previous majority of 2,353 votes. The result was considered one of the most important seat changes of the night; O'Mara had not expected to win the seat. His acceptance speech called for politicians to do more to stand up for disabled people.{{Cite web|url=http://www.thestar.co.uk/news/this-response-from-first-time-sheffield-mp-jared-o-mara-to-a-career-advisor-twenty-years-ago-is-inspiring-1-8590591|title=This response from first time Sheffield MP Jared O'Mara to a career advisor twenty years ago is inspiring|last=Windham|first=Dan|date=12 June 2017|website=The Star|archive-url=|archivedate=|dead-url=|accessdate=14 June 2017}} Given his disability, the buildings of the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] have presented problems for O'Mara as the terms of the [[Equality Act 2010]] are yet to be met.{{cite news|last=Pring|first=John|url= https://www.disabilitynewsservice.com/disabled-mp-forced-to-miss-commons-debates-because-he-has-nowhere-to-sit/|title=Disabled MP forced to miss Commons debates because he has nowhere to sit|work=Disability News Service|date=6 July 2017|accessdate=7 July 2017}} O'Mara asked his first written question in October 2017.https://www.theyworkforyou.com/search/?s=section%3Awrans&pid=25636&pop=1&o=o === Labour whip suspension over offensive online comments === O'Mara became a member of the [[Women and Equalities Committee|Women and Equalities]] [[Select committee (United Kingdom)|Select Committee]] in September 2017. Following revelations of offensive comments he had made before becoming an MP, he resigned from the committee the following month.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/jared-o-mara-labour-mp-women-equalities-committee-resign-sexist-homophobic-online-a8016161.html|title=Jared O'Mara: Labour MP resigns from equalities committee after series of sexist comments revealed|work=The Independent|date=23 October 2017|accessdate=23 October 2017}} A series of derogatory comments about women and gay men posted by O'Mara on websites over a decade before he became an MP were revealed by the [[Paul Staines|Guido Fawkes blog]] on 23 October 2017.{{cite news|url=https://www.itv.com/news/2017-10-23/labour-mp-jared-omara-quits-select-committee-role-over-offensive-online-comments/|title=Labour MP Jared O'Mara quits select committee role over offensive online comments|publisher=ITV News|date=23 October 2017|accessdate=24 October 2017}}{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/oct/24/jared-omara-mp-has-changed-significantly-since-posting-offensive-comments |title=Labour MP who posted offensive comments 'merits second chance' |last=Elgot |first=Jessica |newspaper=The Guardian |date=24 October 2017 |accessdate=24 October 2017}} He commented about the [[Girls Aloud]] pop group: "I advise you to sack [[Sarah Harding|Sarah]] and the remaining four members ([[Nicola Roberts|Nicola]], [[Cheryl (entertainer)|Cheryl]], [[Nadine Coyle|Nadine]] and [[Kimberley Walsh|Kimberley]]) come have an orgy with me"; and he said that the 2003 winner of ''[[Pop Idol]]'', [[Michelle McManus]], had "only won because she was fat".{{cite news|last=Minelle|first=Bethany|url=http://news.sky.com/story/labour-mp-jared-omara-says-hes-ashamed-of-derogatory-remarks-about-celebrities-11095478|title=Labour MP Jared O'Mara says he's 'ashamed' of derogatory remarks about celebrities|publisher=Sky News|date=23 October 2017|accessdate=23 October 2017}} He has also been accused of making homophobic comments including referring to gay men as "poofters" and "fudge packers" and referring to jazz musician [[Jamie Cullum]] as a "conceited cunt" who should be "sodomised with his own piano".{{cite news|last=Maguire|first=Patrick|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/edition/news/labour-mp-facing-dismissal-from-equalities-post-invited-girls-aloud-to-have-an-orgy-in-online-posts-73sjfkr97|title=Labour MP facing dismissal from equalities post invited Girls Aloud to have an orgy in misogynist online posts|work=The Times|date=23 October 2017|accessdate=23 October 2017}} {{subscription required}}{{cite news|url=http://www.pinknews.co.uk/2017/10/23/labour-mp-mocked-fudge-packers-and-poofters-and-lashed-out-at-heterophobes/|title=Labour MP mocked 'fudge packers and poofters' and lashed out at gay 'heterophobes'|work=Pink News|date=23 October 2017|accessdate=23 October 2017}} O'Mara apologised "if his comments caused offence" and resigned from the Women and Equalities Select Committee. The following day, O'Mara was accused by Sophie Evans, a Sheffield bar worker whom he had met through an online dating app, on [[BBC Two]]'s ''[[Daily Politics]]'' of having "made transphobic slurs" towards her in March 2017, and of saying in the same incident that she was an "ugly bitch".{{cite news|last1=Mann|first1=Sebastian|last2=Proctor|first2=Kate|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/politics/jared-omara-under-fire-labour-mp-called-woman-ugly-b-just-weeks-before-he-was-elected-a3666586.html|title=Jared O'Mara: Under fire Labour MP called woman 'ugly b****' just weeks before he was elected|work=London Evening Standard|date=24 October 2017|accessdate=24 October 2017}}{{cite news|last=Walker|first=Peter|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/oct/24/woman-claims-she-was-verbally-abused-by-jared-omara-this-year-sophie-evans|title=Woman claims MP Jared O'Mara verbally abused her this year|work=The Guardian|date=24 October 2017|accessdate=24 October 2017}} O'Mara denied the allegation.{{cite news|last=Horton|first=Helena|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/10/24/jared-omara-refuses-resign-sexist-comments-suggests-conservatives/|title=Jared O'Mara refuses to resign over sexist comments - but suggests Conservatives who make same remarks should step down|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=24 October 2017|accessdate=24 October 2017}} On the same day, it also emerged that he had been posting derogatory comments about children in Sheffield and appeared to advocate corporal punishment to deal with delinquent youth.{{cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/amphtml/jimwaterson/jared-omara-said-sheffield-children-are-into-smoking-crack|title=Jared O'Mara Said Sheffield Children Are Into Smoking Crack And Stealing From Charity Boxes|website=www.buzzfeed.com}} Following the emergence of the comments to Evans, the Labour Party announced an investigation into O'Mara's conduct, but stopped short of suspending him from the party.{{cite news|last=Buchan|first=Lizzie|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/labour-party-jared-o-mara-investigation-verbal-abuse-claims-girls-aloud-jamie-cullum-a8017661.html|title=Labour Party announces investigation into Jared O'Mara MP over verbal abuse claims|work=The Independent|date=24 October 2017|accessdate=24 October 2017}} Further revelations were made public on 25 October 2017. On a [[Morrissey]] fan site in 2002, he was found to have made [[xenophobia|xenophobic insults]], saying that [[Danes]] were "pig shaggers" who "practised [[bestiality]]" and referring to [[Spaniards]] as "[[dagos]]".{{cite news|last=Maguire|first=Patrick|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/edition/news/labour-mp-jared-o-mara-s-sexist-abuse-of-barmaid-5663rg3tf|title=Labour MP Jared O'Mara's 'sexist abuse of barmaid'|work=The Times|date=25 October 2017|accessdate=25 October 2017}} O'Mara, when reviewing the [[Arctic Monkeys]] in November 2004, made several sexual comments including how "sexy little slags" danced to the band's songs.{{cite web|url=https://order-order.com/2017/10/25/jared-sexy-little-slags-teenage-girls-fingered/amp/|title=Jared on "Sexy Little Slags" and Teenage Girls Being "Fingered" - Guido Fawkes|website=order-order.com}} These revelations resulted in O'Mara being suspended from the Labour Party and therefore having the party [[Whip (politics)|whip]] withdrawn. It was reported on 15 January 2018 that O'Mara had not spoken publicly in his constituency since his apology on 23 October. After the party whip was suspended, he cancelled his constituency surgery.{{cite news|url=https://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/news/sheffield-s-missing-mp-how-jared-o-mara-s-political-dream-became-a-nightmare-1-8959343|title=Sheffield's missing MP: How Jared O'Mara's political dream became a nightmare|last=Burn|first=Chris|date=15 January 2018|work=The Yorkshire Post|accessdate=18 January 2018}} In December 2017, a press statement explained that his leave was on the advice of his GP, who had discouraged him from attending Parliament, although O'Mara continued to deal with his constituents' casework.{{cite news|title=MP Jared O'Mara advised by GP not to attend Parliament|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-42336727|publisher=BBC News|date=13 December 2017|accessdate=13 December 2017}} After three months' absence, O'Mara returned to the House of Commons on 17 January 2018 and voted on the report stage of the European Union (Withdrawal) Bill.{{cite news|last1=Line|first1=Harriet|last2=Lister|first2=Sam|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/jared-omara-labour-mp-returns-house-of-commons-suspension-homophobic-sexist-tweets-a8164781.html|title=Jared O’Mara: Labour MP returns to Commons after suspension for homophobic and sexist tweets|work=The Independent|agency=Press Association|date=17 January 2018|accessdate=18 January 2018}} === Reinstatement and resignation from Labour Party === On 3 July 2018, it was announced that O'Mara would be readmitted to the Labour Party, following a review by its [[National Executive Committee]] disputes panel; this review had decided to issue O'Mara a formal warning with a mandatory requirement to attend training, rather than refer the issue to the National Constitutional Committee which has the power to expel members. The decision was criticised by local Liberal Democrats, the closest challengers to Labour in Sheffield Hallam.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-south-yorkshire-44698077|title=Labour reinstates suspended MP O'Mara|last=|first=|date=3 July 2018|work=BBC News|access-date=4 July 2018|language=en-GB}} In an interview with [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] following his readmission, O'Mara said that he had made three attempts on his life during his suspension and had developed an anxiety disorder.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-south-yorkshire-44793195|title=MP's suicide attempts after suspension|last=|first=|date=11 July 2018|work=BBC News|access-date=11 July 2018|language=en-GB}}{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/joepike/status/1016727136642748419?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed&ref_url=http://vote-2012.proboards.com/thread/9872/sheffield-hallam?page=41|title=Joe Pike on Twitter|last=Pike|first=Joe|date=10 July 2018|website=Twitter|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=11 July 2018}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/jul/11/labour-mp-reveals-suicide-attempts-after-storm-over-past-tweets|title=Labour MP reveals suicide attempts after storm over past tweets|last=Parveen|first=Nazia|date=11 July 2018|website=the Guardian|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=11 July 2018}} He also revealed that he is on the autism spectrum,{{Cite news|url=https://twitter.com/joepike/status/1016717267420286976|title=Joe Pike on Twitter|last=Pike|first=Joe|date=10 July 2018|work=Twitter|access-date=11 July 2018|language=en}} and believes that he is the first autistic MP in history.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thestar.co.uk/news/sheffield-mp-jared-o-mara-cuts-back-work-in-westminster-on-doctor-s-orders-days-after-quitting-labour-1-9255330|title=Sheffield MP Jared O'Mara cuts back work in Westminster on doctor's orders days after quitting Labour|last=Blackledge|first=Richard|date=17 July 2018|work=The Star|access-date=19 July 2018|language=en}} O'Mara restated his apology and asked for forgiveness from his constituents and the country.{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/joepike/status/1016728590854090753|title=Joe Pike on Twitter|last=Pike|first=Joe|date=10 July 2018|website=Twitter|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=11 July 2018}} He refused to call a by-election and promised to make his maiden speech in July 2018.{{Cite news|url=https://twitter.com/joepike/status/1016718730833907713|title=Joe Pike on Twitter|last=Pike|first=Joe|date=10 July 2018|work=Twitter|access-date=11 July 2018|language=en}} On 12 July 2018, O'Mara announced his resignation from the Labour Party.{{Cite news|url=https://www.jaredomara.co.uk/recentactivity/2018/7/12/an-open-letter-to-my-constituents|title=An open letter to my constituents.|last=O'Mara|first=Jared|date=12 July 2018|work=Jared O'Mara MP|access-date=12 July 2018|language=en-GB}}{{Cite news|url=https://news.sky.com/story/labour-mp-jared-omara-quits-party-and-hits-out-at-treatment-over-suspension-11435283|title=Labour MP Jared O'Mara quits party and hits out at treatment over suspension|last=McGuinness|first=Alan|date=12 July 2018|work=Sky News|access-date=12 July 2018|language=en-GB}} He said that he had "not been listened to or given a fair investigation" following his suspension, and that the party "no longer shares [his] commitment to the true definition of equality and compassion." Offering to help constituents with casework, he suggested that he would not step down as an MP.{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/jared-omara-quits-labour-party-tweets-twitter-homophobic-sexist-resigns-a8445066.html|title=Jared O'Mara quits Labour Party over handling of homophobic and sexist tweets scandal|last=Khan|first=Shehab|date=12 July 2018|work=The Independent|access-date=12 July 2018|language=en-GB}} Despite his resignation, the Labour Party affirmed that it would continue to provide support for O'Mara; this was on the orders of Corbyn, who was concerned for O'Mara's welfare.{{Cite news|url=http://www.itv.com/news/calendar/2018-07-16/labour-will-continue-to-provide-support-for-now-independent-mp-jared-omara/|title=Labour will continue to provide support for now independent MP Jared O'Mara|last=|first=|date=16 July 2018|work=ITV News|access-date=19 July 2018|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/news/labour-to-continue-offer-of-support-to-sheffield-hallam-mp-jared-o-mara-1-9254196|title=Labour to 'continue offer of support' to Sheffield Hallam MP Jared O’Mara|last=Blow|first=John|date=16 July 2018|work=Yorkshire Post|access-date=19 July 2018|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=http://forgetoday.com/2018/07/18/sheffield-mp-jared-omara-cuts-back-westminster-duties-on-health-grounds/|title=Sheffield MP Jared O’Mara cuts back Westminster duties on health grounds|last=O'Callaghan|first=Niall|date=18 July 2018|website=forgetoday.com|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=19 July 2018}} On 18 July 2018, O'Mara announced that he would step back from his parliamentary duties on the advice of his [[General practitioner|GP]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-south-yorkshire-44869862|title=MP to cut back duties on health grounds|last=|first=|date=18 July 2018|work=BBC News|access-date=19 July 2018|language=en-GB}} This coincided with a series of crucial votes on the [[Brexit negotiations]], for which reason O'Mara had unsuccessfully applied to vote by proxy. O'Mara has never asked an [[Question time#United Kingdom|oral question]], and made his [[maiden speech]] on 24 July 2018,{{cite web|url=https://hansard.parliament.uk/Commons/2018-07-24/debates/9DF2F3F9-C84E-4556-859A-AE233091A9AD/SummerAdjournment#contribution-6C888F63-1A88-4B75-9027-22F8ACCAE12B|title=Summer Adjournment - Hansard|access-date=26 July 2018}} the day before the start of the summer recess.{{cite web|url=https://www.parliament.uk/about/faqs/house-of-commons-faqs/business-faq-page/recess-dates/|title=House of Commons recess dates|access-date=26 July 2018}} He was the 84th and final MP of the 2017 intake to make a maiden speech; the 83rd, [[David Duguid (politician)|David Duguid]], spoke in November 2017.{{cite news |title=Opposition calls for universal credit changes |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/live/uk-politics-parliaments-41971478 |accessdate=27 July 2018 |work=BBC News |date=16 November 2017}}{{cite news|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/edition/news/tie-privilege-is-wasted-on-commons-ghost-c5bpt7wnq|title=Tie privilege is wasted on Commons ghost|last1=Kidd|first1=Patrick|date=26 October 2017|work=The Times|accessdate=26 October 2017}}{{cite news|url=http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/news/opinion/the-yorkshire-post-says-jared-o-mara-is-betraying-faith-of-sheffield-voters-1-8821765|title=The Yorkshire Post says: Jared O'Mara is betraying faith of Sheffield voters|date=25 October 2017|work=Yorkshire Post|accessdate=26 October 2017}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commonscat}} *{{UK MP links |parliament=jared-o%27mara/4661 |publicwhip=Jared_O%26%2339%3BMara |theywork=jared_o'mara}} {{S-start}} {{s-par|uk}} {{s-bef | before = [[Nick Clegg]] }} {{s-ttl | title = Member of Parliament for {{nowrap|[[Sheffield Hallam (UK Parliament constituency)|Sheffield Hallam]]}} | years = [[United Kingdom general election, 2017|2017]]–present {{s-inc}} }} {{S-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:O'Mara, Jared}} [[Category:1981 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People educated at Tapton School]] [[Category:Alumni of Staffordshire University]] [[Category:UK MPs 2017–]] [[Category:Labour Party (UK) MPs for English constituencies]] [[Category:People with cerebral palsy]] [[Category:People from Sheffield]] [[Category:Independent members of the House of Commons of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:People on the autism spectrum]]

'''Jean Fox O'Barr''' (born 1942) is a leading feminist teacher, scholar, and administrator whose pioneering work helped establish [[women’s studies]] as a program of academic study and support for women in higher education.
O'Barr received her undergraduate degree from [[Indiana University]] in 1964 and her Master’s (1965) and PhD (1970) in Political Science from [[Northwestern University]]. She also earned a certificate in African Studies from Northwestern in 1970 based on her graduate work in [[Tanzania]].
Change magazine named her among One Hundred Outstanding Young Leaders in Education in 1978, and O'Barr was selected for the Ford and Exxon Education Foundation’s study of 25 influential female leaders of the women’s movement.<ref name="IUHonoree">{{cite web|title=Honoree: Jean Fox O'Barr|url=http://www.iu.edu/~uha/search-awards/honoree.shtml?honoreeID=388|work=Indiana University Honors & Awards|accessdate=20 March 2014}}</ref>
O’Barr is the founding director of [[Duke University]] Women’s Studies Program and led the program for almost 20 years (1983-2001). In 2000, she was named Distinguished University Service Professor at Duke University, the first woman to be named in school history. O'Barr has won numerous awards for teaching and mentoring. In 2010, she was awarded with one of Duke's highest awards, the University Medal for Distinguished Meritorious Service.<ref>{{cite news|last=Lawrence|first=Keith|title=Founder's Day Convocation Sept. 30 in Duke Chapel|url=https://today.duke.edu/2010/09/founders_day.html|accessdate=20 March 2014|newspaper=Duke Today|date=22 September 2010}}</ref>
O'Barr has written nearly 100 articles and books,<ref name="IUHonoree" /> including ''Transforming Knowledge: Public Talks on Women’s Studies 1976-2011'' (2013),<ref name="WUNC">{{cite web|title=Founder Of Duke's Women's Studies Department Discusses Evolution Of Women's Scholarship|url=http://wunc.org/post/founder-dukes-womens-studies-department-discusses-evolution-womens-scholarship|work=The State of Things|publisher=WUNC 91.5 North Carolina Public Radio|accessdate=26 March 2014|author=Nicole Campbell|author2=Frank Stasio|date=September 16, 2013}}</ref> ''Feminism in Action: Building Community and Institutions through Women’s Studies'' (1995), ''Women Imagine Change: A Global Anthology of Women's Resistance from 600 B.C.E. to Present'' (1997; with Eugenia DeLamotte and Natania Meeke), and ''Africa in the Disciplines: Contributions of the Study of Africa to the Humanities and Social Sciences'' (1993; with Robert H. Yates and Valentin Y. Mudimbe). She also served as editor-in-chief of ''[[Signs (journal)|Signs: Journal of Women in Culture and Society]]'', the leading international journal in women's studies, and co-founded the Sallie Bingham Center for Women’s History and Culture, part of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library at Duke University. Her papers are housed at the Bingham Center.
== Selected works ==
''Articles'' *J.F. O'Barr. "The Movement to Establish Women's Studies." Encyclopedia of Social Movements 2 (2004): 415-421. *J.F. O'Barr. "My Master List for the Millenium: Commissioned essay." SIGNS: Journal of Women in Society and Culture (special issue) 25.4 (Summer, 2000): 1205-1208. (Reprinted in Judith Howard and Carolyn Allen, eds. Feminisms at a Millenium (Chicago: University of Chicago) 2001, 202-204.) *J.F. O'Barr and Kathryn Firmin-Sellers. "African Women in Politics." African Women South of the Sahara all new chapter, revised edition (January, 1995). *J.F. O'Barr. "Making the Invisible Visible: African Women in Politics and Policy." African Studies Review 18 (1975): 19-27. *J.F. O'Barr. "Report on Changes in Tanzanian Rural Society and Their Relevance for Development Planning." Rural Africana 13 (1971): 43-49.
''Books'' *J.F. O'Barr. Transforming Knowledge: Public Talks on Women’s Studies 1976-2011. 2013. *J.F. O'Barr with Eugenia DeLamotte and Natania Meeker. Women Imagine Change: A Global Anthology of Women's Resistance from 600 BCE to Present. New York: Routledge, 1997. *J.F. O'Barr, with Nancy Hewitt and Nanvy Rosebaugh, eds.. Talking Gender: Public Images, Personal Journeys, and Political Critiques. Chapel Hill, NC: University of North Carolina, 1996. *J.F. O'Barr. Feminism in Action: Building Institutions and Community Through Women's Studies. Chapel Hill, NC: University of North Carolina, 1994. *J.F. O'Barr with Robert H. Yates and Valentin Y. Mudimbe, eds.. Africa and the Disciplines: Contributions of the Study of Africa to the Humanities and Social Sciences. Chicago: University of Chicago, 1993.

{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Jodi Huisentruit | image = Jodi Huisentruit.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Jodi Sue Huisentruit | birth_date = {{Birth date|1968|6|5}} | birth_place = [[Long Prairie, Minnesota]], U.S. | disappeared_date = {{Disappeared date and age|1995|6|27|1968|6|5}} | disappeared_place = [[Mason City, Iowa]], U.S. | disappeared_status = {{Missing for|1995|6|27}} | death_date = declared legally dead May 2001= | nationality = [[Americans|American]] | other_names = | known_for = | education = St. Cloud State University | occupation = Television news anchor }}
'''Jodi Sue Huisentruit''' (born June 5, 1968 – declared legally dead May 2001) was a [[television]] [[news anchor]] for [[KIMT]], based in [[Mason City, Iowa]], in the [[United States]]. She was declared missing in the early morning hours of June 27, 1995, soon after telling a colleague that she was on her way to work. As there were signs of a struggle outside her apartment, she is believed to have been [[kidnapping|abducted]], but extensive investigations have failed to uncover any clues to her disappearance.
==Early life== Huisentruit was born in and grew up in [[Long Prairie, Minnesota]],<ref>{{cite news|last1=Pieper|first1=Mary|title=Search for Jodi Huisentruit continues 20 years later|url=http://globegazette.com/news/local/search-for-jodi-huisentruit-continues-years-later/article_ccb4f1f6-bf83-5c06-835c-3d27daeff8e0.html|accessdate=April 13, 2016|work=[[Globe Gazette]]|date=June 27, 2015}}</ref> the youngest daughter of Maurice Nicholas Huisentruit (1920–1982) and Imogene L. "Jane" Huisentruit (née Anderson, 1923–2014).<ref>{{cite news|last1=Peterson|first1=Gary|title=Remembering Imogene 'Jane' Huisentruit|url=http://www.findjodi.com/remembering-imogene-jane-huisentruit/|accessdate=January 1, 2017|work=Find Jodi|date=December 11, 2014}}</ref> In [[high school]], she was considered to be very good at [[golf]]. Her team won the state Class A tournament in 1985 and 1986. After high school, she went on to [[St. Cloud State University]], where she studied mass communications and speech communication and graduated with a [[Bachelor's degree]] in 1990. Her first job after graduation was with [[Northwest Airlines]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Molene|first1=John|title=Family plants endowment seed|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/223293183|accessdate=January 14, 2017|work=[[St. Cloud Times]]|date=October 25, 1997|pages=3A–4A}}</ref> She entered broadcasting by getting a job at [[KGAN]] in [[Cedar Rapids, Iowa]], as the station's Iowa City bureau chief, then returned to [[Minnesota]] for a job at [[KSAX]] in [[Alexandria, Minnesota|Alexandria]] before returning to [[Iowa]] for her KIMT position.
==Disappearance== On the day before she disappeared, Huisentruit participated in a golf tournament and, according to Mason City resident John Vansice, she went to his home to view a video tape of the birthday party that he had arranged for her earlier in the month.<ref>[http://www.findjodi.com/ FindJodi.com, The search continues]</ref>
At about 4:00 am on Tuesday, June 27, 1995, KIMT [[Television producer|producer]] Amy Kuns noted that Huisentruit had failed to report to work as scheduled, so she called Huisentruit's apartment. Huisentruit answered the telephone, explained that she had overslept, and said she was preparing to leave for the station. By 6:00 am, however, she had still not arrived, and Kuns filled in for her on the morning show ''Daybreak''. At about 7:00 am, KIMT staff called the Mason City [[police]].<ref name="ABC2005">{{cite news|title=Community Still Haunted by Missing News Anchor|url=http://abcnews.go.com/2020/story?id=893514|accessdate=January 1, 2017|work=[[ABC News]]|date=July 1, 2005}}</ref>
When police arrived at Huisentruit's apartment they found her red [[Mazda Miata]] in the parking lot, as well as evidence suggesting there had been a struggle near that car. Among other evidence, Huisentruit's personal items, including a bent car key,<ref name="bent key">{{cite web |title=Jodi Huisentruit |url=https://truecrimegarage.com/listen |website=True Crime Garage |accessdate=8 June 2018}}</ref> were found strewn about the area and police reported recovering an unidentified palm print from her car.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Mastre|first1=Brian|title=Cold Case: News Anchor Abducted|url=http://www.wowt.com/home/headlines/Cold-Case-News-Anchor-Abducted-309934101.html|accessdate=April 13, 2016|publisher=[[WOWT]]|date=July 10, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=20 years later, TV anchor Jodi Huisentruit still missing|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/20-years-later-tv-anchor-jodi-huisentruit-still-missing/|accessdate=April 13, 2016|work=[[CBS News]]|date=June 25, 2015}}</ref>
==Investigation== The ensuing investigation revealed at least three neighbors in her apartment complex who said they heard screams at about the time Huisentruit would have likely been leaving for work.<ref>{{cite news|title=Officials still searching for missing newswoman|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1907&dat=19950629&id=MOAxAAAAIBAJ&pg=4986,3828051|accessdate=April 13, 2016|work=The Daily Reporter<!-- Spencer, Iowa -->|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=June 29, 1995}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Divine|first1=Mary|title=20 years later, search for Jodi Huisentruit hasn't ended|url=http://www.twincities.com/2015/06/19/20-years-later-search-for-jodi-huisentruit-hasnt-ended/|accessdate=April 13, 2016|work=[[St. Paul Pioneer Press]]|date=June 19, 2015}}</ref> In addition, a neighbor who lived nearby reported seeing a white van with its running lights on parked in Huisentruit's parking lot at about the same time. This van was never positively identified.<ref>{{cite news|title=The strange case of Jodi Huisentruit|url=http://www.shieldsgazette.com/news/offbeat/the-strange-case-of-jodi-huisentruit-1-6976073|accessdate=April 13, 2016|work=The Shields Gazette|date=November 27, 2014}}</ref>
In September 1995, the Huisentruit family hired [[private investigator]]s from McCarthy & Associates, Investigative Services, Inc. (MAIS) in [[Minneapolis, Minnesota]], who in turn enlisted the assistance of [[Omaha, Nebraska]] private investigator Doug Jasa. McCarthy and Jasa appeared on several national television shows, including ''[[America's Most Wanted]]'' and ''[[Unsolved Mysteries]]''.<ref>Episode Number: 364; Season: 8; First Aired: February 18, 1996</ref> In November 1995, they and members of Jodi's family traveled to [[Los Angeles]] to meet with three prominent [[psychics]]. This meeting was televised and served as the pilot for the ''[[Psychic Detectives]]'' television show.<ref>{{cite news|title=Psychics join search for anchorwoman|url=http://www.postbulletin.com/psychics-join-search-for-anchorwoman/article_cf1251be-5e9b-5420-b6bd-45c501cbe2e4.html|accessdate=January 1, 2017|work=[[Post-Bulletin]]|date=November 13, 1995}}</ref> Although each show generated a large volume of leads, none resulted in concrete evidence or the identification of a suspect.
In May 1996, about 100 volunteers searched an area of [[Cerro Gordo County]] and left flags to mark anything that appeared suspicious. Each of these sites was then re-examined by law enforcement, but no promising evidence was located.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Benson|first1=Josh|title=Jodi's Disappearance: 1st Year Timeline|url=http://www.findjodi.com/jodis-disappearance-1st-year-timeline/|accessdate=January 1, 2017|work=Find Jodi}}</ref>
Since Huisentruit's disappearance in 1995, police and private investigators have conducted more than 1000 interviews relating to her disappearance.<ref>{{cite news|title=Year later, TV anchor still missing|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1310&dat=19960630&id=CElWAAAAIBAJ&pg=6019,7908075|accessdate=April 13, 2016|work=[[Eugene Register-Guard]]|agency=Associated Press|date=June 30, 1996}}</ref><ref>[http://www.kcci.com/news/3532941/detail.html Sheriff: Human Remains From Adult Male – Des Moines News Story – KCCI Des Moines<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605230812/http://www.kcci.com/news/3532941/detail.html |date=June 5, 2011 }}</ref> None have resulted in conclusive evidence pointing towards a suspect. Huisentruit was declared legally dead in May 2001.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bob|first1=Link|title=Court declares Jodi Huisentruit legally dead|url=http://globegazette.com/news/local/court-declares-jodi-huisentruit-legally-dead/article_408d26b3-ded6-5f85-a323-505532e796cc.html|accessdate=January 1, 2017|work=[[Globe Gazette]]|date=May 15, 2001}}</ref>
There have been periodic resurgences in the story. When new cases arise that appear to bear similarities to Huisentruit's or remains are found in the area, speculation quickly leads to a connection with the missing reporter. So far, however, no suspect has been tied to Huisentruit's disappearance and all remains have proven to be from other sources. In 2005, many media outlets, including ''[[20/20 (US television series)|20/20]]'',<ref>20/20 Episode Number: 1405; Season: 26; First Aired: Friday July 1, 2005</ref> again focused on the story as the 10th anniversary of the disappearance approached.
In early June 2008, photocopies of the 84 pages of Huisentruit's personal journal were anonymously mailed to a local newspaper.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.startribune.com/local/20660704.html?page=1&c=y |title=Journal of missing television anchor mailed to newspaper |work=Star Tribune |accessdate=March 26, 2014 |agency=Associated Press |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080626222545/http://www.startribune.com/local/20660704.html?page=1&c=y |archivedate=June 26, 2008 }}</ref> The Mason City ''[[Globe Gazette]]'' received the material in a large envelope with no return address and a June 4 postmark from Waterloo, Iowa. The original journal has been in the possession of law enforcement since the investigation of Huisentruit's disappearance began.<ref>[http://www.globegazette.com/articles/2008/06/22/news/local/doc485dc763e49ee406478527.txt "Jodi's Journal"], ''The Globe Gazette'', June 22, 2008</ref> Within days, Mason City Police reported that the sender had come forward and then identified her as the wife of the former Mason City Police Chief. Although noting that the former chief had taken a copy of the journal home when he left office, the police gave no motive for his wife sending the copy to the newspaper.<ref>{{cite news|title=Wife of former police chief sent Huisentruit journal to Globe|url=http://globegazette.com/news/wife-of-former-police-chief-sent-huisentruit-journal-to-globe/article_0af9999f-4c3d-5a97-a8ba-c49b88238a0a.html|accessdate=April 13, 2016|work=Globe Gazette|date=June 27, 2008}}</ref>
The FBI, the Mason City Police Department, the Iowa Division of Criminal Investigation, and MAIS's investigators are all still actively working on Huisentruit's disappearance, and the television show ''Nancy Grace: America's Missing'' spotlighted her case on February 23, 2011, and again on December 6, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=Newswoman Missing in Mason City, Iowa|url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/1102/23/ng.01.html|accessdate=May 16, 2017|publisher=CNN|date=February 23, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Nancy Grace Mysteries: Jodi Huisentruit|url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/1312/06/ng.01.html|publisher=CNN|accessdate=May 16, 2017|date=December 6, 2013}}</ref>
In May 2015, all 100 members of the Iowa State House of Representatives signed a letter asking for the City of Mason City to declare June 27, 2015, as Jodi Huisentruit Day in honor of her memory and that of all victims in unsolved cases.
In December 2016, retiring Iowa State Representative [[John Kooiker]] of [[Sioux County, Iowa]], described his experience with the case as a member of the Iowa State House Public Safety Committee and suggested a cover-up by Mason City officials. His opinion piece was published in ''The N'West Iowa Review''.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kooiker|first1=John|title=Disappearance of Huisentruit remains troubling|url=http://www.nwestiowa.com/opinion/kooiker-disappearance-of-huisentruit-remains-troubling/article_2f7fbefc-cc7c-11e6-ba1c-7badde849db6.html|accessdate=March 11, 2017|publisher=The N'West Iowa Review|date=December 28, 2016}}</ref>
In March 2017, a search warrant was executed against person of interest John Vansice seeking GPS data for two of his vehicles.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Miller|first1=Ashley|title=Mason City search warrant against person of interest in Huisentruit case remains sealed (with photos, video)|url=http://globegazette.com/news/local/crime-and-courts/mason-city-search-warrant-against-person-of-interest-in-huisentruit/article_f4a53f25-27fe-5f63-afa6-6cf43f17ceef.html|accessdate=March 16, 2018|work=Mason City Globe Gazette|date=March 16, 2018}}</ref>
{{as of|2018}}, Huisentruit has not been found, neither have remains been identified as hers.

[[File:Johnny Depp 2, 2011.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Johnny Depp at the [[Austin Film Festival]] premiere of ''[[The Rum Diary (film)|The Rum Diary]]'' in October 2011]] [[Johnny Depp| John Christopher Depp II]] is an American actor, director, screen writer, film producer,art director and musician. He started his film career by playing [[List of characters in the Nightmare on Elm Street series#Glen Lantz|Glen Lantz]] in the 1984 horror film ''[[A Nightmare on Elm Street]]''. He also appeared in the 1986 film ''[[Platoon (film)|Platoon]]'' with [[Charlie Sheen]], [[Tom Berenger]], and [[Willem Dafoe]]. In the 1990s, the starred as the title characters in the films ''[[Cry-Baby]]'' (1990), ''[[Edward Scissorhands]]'' (1990), ''[[Arizona Dream]]'' (1993), ''[[What's Eating Gilbert Grape]]'' (1993), Benny and Joon 1993 romantic drama ''[[Ed Wood (film)|Ed Wood]]'' (1994), ''[[Don Juan DeMarco]]'' (1995), Dead Man (1995) and ''[[Donnie Brasco (film)|Donnie Brasco]]'' (1997). He also starred in ''[[Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas (film)|Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas]]'' as [[Hunter S. Thompson]] (1998), ''[[The Ninth Gate]]'' as Dean Corso (1999), and ''[[Sleepy Hollow (film)|Sleepy Hollow]]'' as [[Ichabod Crane]] (1999). In the 2000s, he was in the films ''[[Chocolat (2000 film)|Chocolat]]'' (2000), ''[[Blow (film)|Blow]]'' (2001), ''[[From Hell (film)|From Hell]]'' (2001), ''[[Once Upon a Time in Mexico]]'' (2003), ''[[Finding Neverland (film)|Finding Neverland]]'' (2004), ''[[Charlie and the Chocolate Factory (film)|Charlie and the Chocolate Factory]]'' (2005), ''[[Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007 film)|Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street]]'' (2007), and ''[[Public Enemies (2009 film)|Public Enemies]]'' (2009). He has played [[Jack Sparrow|Captain Jack Sparrow]] in the [[Pirates of the Caribbean (film series)|''Pirates of the Caribbean'' series]], starting with 2003's ''[[Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl|The Curse of the Black Pearl]]'', and going on to reprise the role in ''[[Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest|Dead Man's Chest]]'' (2006), ''[[Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End|At World's End]]'' (2007), ''[[Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides|On Stranger Tides]]'' (2011) and ''[[Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales|Dead Men Tell No Tales]]'' (2017). For his roles in ''The Curse of the Black Pearl'', ''Finding Neverland'', and ''Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street'', Depp was nominated for an [[Academy Award for Best Actor]]. In 2010, Depp was cast as the [[The Hatter|Mad Hatter]] in the live-action film ''[[Alice in Wonderland (2010 film)|Alice in Wonderland]]''. The same year, he went on to star in ''[[The Tourist (2010 film)|The Tourist]]'' with [[Angelina Jolie]] and was nominated for a [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy|Golden Globe Award for Best Actor in a Motion Picture Comedy]]. He has starred in ''[[The Rum Diary (film)|The Rum Diary]]'' with [[Amber Heard]] (2011), ''[[Dark Shadows (film)|Dark Shadows]]'' with [[Michelle Pfeiffer]] (2012), ''[[The Lone Ranger (2013 film)|The Lone Ranger]]'' with [[Armie Hammer]] (2013), and ''[[Transcendence (2014 film)|Transcendence]]'' (2014) with [[Morgan Freeman]]. His television work includes playing Officer Thomas "Tom" Hanson, Jr. in the [[crime drama]] ''[[21 Jump Street]]'' from 1987 to 1990. He has also lent his voice to the animated series ''[[King of the Hill]]'' in 2004, ''[[SpongeBob SquarePants]]'' in 2009, and ''[[Family Guy]]'' in 2012. Depp has been described as one of the most versatile and prolific actors of his generation.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thequint.com/entertainment/.../the-versatile-johnny-depp-over-the-years|title=The Versatile Johnny Depp Over the Years|work=The Quint|access-date=2018-09-29|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://studybreaks.com/thoughts/johnny-depp-admits-using-an-earpiece-while-acting/|title=Johnny Depp Admits to Using an Earpiece, as Well as Generally Falling Apart|date=2018-06-28|work=Study Breaks|access-date=2018-09-29|language=en-US}} ==Filmography== ===Film=== {| class="wikitable sortable"
