==Tours== {{Div col|colwidth=28em}} *[[Foot Loose & Fancy Free Tour]] (1977) *Blondes 'Ave More Fun Tour (1978–1979) *[[Foolish Behaviour Tour]] (1980–1981) *[[Worth Leavin' Home For Tour]] (1981–1982) *[[Body Wishes Tour]] (1983) *[[Camouflage Tour]] (1984–1985) *Every Beat Of My Heart Tour (1986) *[[Out of Order Tour]] (1988–1989) *Vagabond Heart Tour (1991–1992) *A Night to Remember Tour (1993–1994) *[[A Spanner in the Works Tour]] (1995–1996) *All Rod, All Night, All The Hits Tour (1998–1999) *Human Tour (2001) *Live In Concert Tour (2002) *From Maggie May To The Great American Songbook Tour (2004) *Tour (2005) *Rockin' In The Round Tour (2007) *Rocks His Greatest Hits Tour (2008–2009) *One Rockin' Night Tour (2009) *[[Soulbook Tour]] (2010) *[[Heart & Soul Tour]] (2011–2012) <small> with [[Stevie Nicks]] </small> *[[Live the Life Tour]] (2013) *[[The Voice, The Guitar, The Songs Tour]] (2014) <small> with [[Santana (band)|Santana]] </small> *[[From Gasoline Alley to Another Country: Hits 2016]] (2016) *Summer Tour 2017 <small>(with [[Cyndi Lauper]]) (2017)</small> *Summer Tour 2018 <small>(with [[Cyndi Lauper]]) (2018)</small> {{Div col end}}
===Residency show=== *[[Rod Stewart: The Hits]] (2011–2017)

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2014}} {{Use South African English|date=December 2014}} '''Ryan Coetzee''' (born 8 January 1973) is a [[South Africa]]n politician and political strategist, who has served as [[special adviser (UK government)|special adviser]] to [[Deputy Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]] [[Nick Clegg]]<ref name="Tele01">{{Cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/9682476/Spads-bill-rises-to-levels-seen-under-Gordon-Brown.html |title=Spads bill rises to levels seen under Gordon Brown |date=16 November 2012 |work=The Telegraph |access-date=30 April 2017}}</ref> and was the 2015 General Election Director of Strategy at Liberal Democrat HQ.<ref name="LDV01">{{Cite news |url=http://www.libdemvoice.org/ryan-coetzee-switches-from-cleggs-director-of-strategy-to-lib-dems-general-election-director-of-strategy-42021.html |title=Ryan Coetzee switches from Clegg’s Director of Strategy to Lib Dems’ General Election Director of Strategy |last=Tall |first=Stephan |date=12 August 2014 |work=Liberal Democrat Voice |access-date=30 April 2017}}</ref> In 2016, he was director of strategy for the campaign for the UK to remain in the EU.
He previously served as a Member of [[South Africa]]'s [[Parliament of South Africa|Parliament]] between 2004 and 2008, as CEO of South Africa's official opposition party, the [[Democratic Alliance (South Africa)|Democratic Alliance]] between 2004 and 2009, and as the party's general election campaign chief in 2006, 2009, and 2011.<ref name="M&G01">{{Cite news |url=https://mg.co.za/article/2009-06-30-navigating-the-corridors-of-power |title=Navigating the corridors of power |date=30 June 2009 |work=Mail&Guardian |access-date=30 April 2017}}</ref> He served as chief adviser to [[Western Cape]] Premier [[Helen Zille]] between 2009 and 2012.<ref name="IOL01">{{Cite news |url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/da-whizz-kid-to-be-zilles-chief-adviser-447435 |title=DA whizz kid to be Zille's chief adviser |last=du Plessis |first=Carien |date=25 June 2009 |work=IOL |access-date=30 April 2017}}</ref>
==Background== Coetzee holds a Bachelor of Arts and a Higher Diploma in Education, both from the University of Cape Town.
==Career in politics== In 1997 Coetzee was picked by DP leader [[Tony Leon]] to head up the party's parliamentary operations at the age of 24. Leon subsequently noted Coetzee's appointment as "the most significant" he made during his 13-year tenure as leader of the party.<ref name="leon">Tony Leon, ''On The Contrary'', 2008, Jonathan Ball, {{ISBN|978-1-86842-305-7}}, pg. 298</ref> From 1999, Coetzee was the party's chief strategist, playing a central role in the party's election campaigns,<ref>[http://www.bdlive.co.za/articles/2011/06/27/management-strategy-is-the-political-steering-wheel "Strategy is the steering wheel"]</ref> which saw the DA grow from 1.7% in 1994 to 24.2% in the 2011 local government elections.
In April 2004 Coetzee became a Member of Parliament, and was assigned the shadow health portfolio. Six months later he famously asked then President [[Thabo Mbeki]] during a Parliamentary debate whether he believed the high rate of sexual violence in South Africa contributed towards the spread of HIV, and whether the President actually believed [[AIDS denialism|HIV causes AIDS]]. Mbeki responded by accusing Coetzee of succumbing to the "disease of racism", but avoided responding directly, thus reigniting criticism of his government's response to the pandemic.<ref name="IOL02">{{Cite news |url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/mbeki-refuses-to-be-drawn-on-aids-issue-224789 |title=Mbeki refuses to be drawn on Aids issue |last=Quintal |first=Angela |date=22 October 2004 |work=IOL |access-date=30 April 2017}}</ref>
In 2005, Coetzee was appointed the DA's CEO, in which role he radically reorganised the party and its finances, and designed and managed the 2006 local government election campaign and the 2009 general election campaign. In 2008, he oversaw a relaunch of the party designed to position it as a party of government, and not merely one of opposition.<ref name="M&G02">{{Cite news |url=https://mg.co.za/article/2008-11-10-da-plans-relaunch-to-grow-support-base |title=DA plans 'relaunch' to grow support base |date=10 November 2008 |work=Mail&Guardian |access-date=30 April 2017}}</ref>
In 2009, Coetzee resigned as party CEO to become a Special Advisor to the Premier of the Western Cape and party leader Helen Zille, with a brief to co-ordinate government policy and strategy. He was succeeded as DA CEO by [[Jonathan Moakes]].
In September 2012, in a surprise move, [[Nick Clegg]] appointed Coetzee strategy director of the [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrats]] in Britain. In late October 2013 it was announced that Coetzee might return to South Africa and was being offered a Western Cape provincial cabinet post by the DA.<ref name="ExSpinDr">{{cite web | url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/ex-spin-doctor-tipped-for-da-post-1.1594803#.UmUdGvlmim4 | title=Ex-spin doctor tipped for DA post | publisher=Cape Argus | date=21 October 2013 | accessdate=21 October 2013 | author=Meyer, Warda}}</ref> However, in August 2014 he instead switched to a job at Liberal Democrat party HQ, becoming the General Election Director of Strategy, for which he was reportedly paid a salary of £110,000.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/politics/592638/Eure-Referendum-yes-campaign-Ryan-Coetzee-Lib-Dem|title=Lib Dem election 'guru' - who won the party EIGHT seats - to lead 'in' campaign for Europe|last=Henn|first=Peter|date=2015-07-21|work=Express.co.uk|access-date=2018-10-19|language=en}}</ref><ref name="Tele02">{{Cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/general-election-2015/10811693/General-election-2015-the-strategists-Ryan-Coetzee-Liberal-Democrats.html |title=General election 2015 - the strategists: Ryan Coetzee, Liberal Democrats |last=Dominiczak |first=Peter |date=7 May 2014 |work=The Telegraph |access-date=30 April 2017}}</ref><ref name="LDV02">{{Cite news |url=http://www.libdemvoice.org/ryan-coetzee-switches-from-cleggs-director-of-strategy-to-lib-dems-general-election-director-of-strategy-42021.html |title=Ryan Coetzee switches from Clegg’s Director of Strategy to Lib Dems’ General Election Director of Strategy |last=Tall |first=Stephen |date=12 August 2014 |work=Liberal Democrat Voice |access-date=30 April 2017}}</ref>
The Liberal Democrats faired very badly in the UK 2015 General Election, losing most of their seats. Coetzee is viewed as having led the party into oblivion.<ref name="INP01">{{Cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/editorials/europe-or-bust-the-campaign-to-keep-the-uk-in-the-eu-is-lagging-and-needs-charismatic-leadership-a6686926.html |title=Europe or bust: Campaign to keep the UK in the EU is lagging and needs charismatic leadership |date=8 October 2015 |work=Independent |access-date=30 April 2017}}</ref> Writing for ''The Guardian'' after the result, Coetzee said, "We got routed by what I call the Fear. We presumed from the beginning that the Conservatives would try to scare voters with the prospect of a Miliband government that would risk the economy. But in the event the polls and the SNP conspired to ratchet up the Fear to Terror levels, because they showed Labour’s only path to power would be via the SNP."<ref name="GRD01">{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/may/22/liberal-democrats-opposition-labour-government |title=The Liberal Democrats must reunite, rebuild or remain in opposition |last=Coetzee |first=Ryan |date=23 May 2015 |work=The Guardian |access-date=30 April 2017}}</ref>
During the summer of 2015, Coetzee joined Britain in Europe, the pro-European referendum campaign organisation.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/lib-dem-guru-joins-pro-eu-campaign-gqpcshblcbq |title=Lib Dem guru joins pro EU campaign |date=21 July 2015 |work=The Times |access-date=30 April 2017}}</ref> The campaign is seen as lacking in charismatic leadership.<ref name=INP01/> As Director of Strategy for the 'Stronger In' campaign, Coetzee was relatively quiet, writing publicly once in a South African newspaper to comment on the 2016 UK budget and difficulties within the UK Conservative Party.<ref name="BD01">{{Cite news |url=http://www.bdlive.co.za/opinion/2016/03/29/uk-conservatives-snared-by-budget-trap-set-for-labour |title=UK Conservatives snared by budget trap set for Labour |last=Coetzee |first=Ryan |date=29 March 2016 |work=BusinessDay |access-date=30 April 2017}}</ref> In the June 2016 referendum the UK voted to leave the EU, and Ryan Coetzee blamed the defeat in a tweet on "25 years of right wing tabloid propaganda".<ref name="Tweet01">{{Cite tweet |number=746091317915193344 |user=RyanCoetzee |title=And we were up against 25 years of right wing tabloid propaganda. |date=23 June 2016 |access-date=30 April 2017}}</ref>
== Personal life == Coetzee has a son, Daniel Jackson Coetzee, born on 20 October 2006.
== References == {{reflist|2}}

revision.comment: Removing from [[Category:American non-fiction writers]] (parent category) using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
{{for|the American cultural curator|Scott Beale (cultural curator)}} {{use American English|date=June 2015}} {{use mdy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Scott Beale<!-- include middle initial, if not specified in birth_name --> | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = 20th century<!-- {{Birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Birth-date and age|birth date†}} --> | birth_place = | occupation = [[Social entrepreneur]], writer | spouse = | parents = }} '''Scott Beale''' (born 20th century) is an American [[social entrepreneur]] who has started three nonprofit organizations. He is the founder and chief executive officer of [[Atlas Service Corps|Atlas Corps]], a leadership development program for nonprofit professionals. Sometimes called a "reverse [[Peace Corps]]", Atlas Corps brings leaders from all around the world to serve in cities across the United States.
==Early life, education and early activism== Beale grew up in [[Delaware]]. A John Carroll Scholar at [[Georgetown University]], he graduated in 1998. Beale also has an [[Master of Public Administration|MPA]] from the [[University of Delaware]].
While an undergraduate at Georgetown University, he organized political rallies at the [[United States Capital|U.S. Capitol]] and registered youth voters for [[Rock the Vote]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Scott Beale: 2010 National Awards Honoree|url=http://uscenterforcitizendiplomacy.org/summit/awards/scott-beale|publisher=[[US Center for Citizen Diplomacy]]|access-date=May 2, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130403232925/http://uscenterforcitizendiplomacy.org/summit/awards/scott-beale|archivedate=April 3, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
==Career== Beale was a U.S. diplomat who served in [[New Delhi]] fighting [[human trafficking]] in [[India]] and in [[Bosnia]] organizing elections in the late 1990s. He also worked at [[Bill Drayton|Ashoka's Youth Venture]] program and in the Clinton White House.
Beale is a co-author with [[Abeer Abdalla]] of ''Millennial Manifesto: A Youth Activist Handbook'' (2003), a book about the politics of the [[Millennials|Millennial Generation]] published through [[self-publishing]] press [[InstantPublisher]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Amazon.com listing for Millennial Manifesto|url=https://www.amazon.com/Millennial-Manifesto-Scott-Beale/dp/1591964210|publisher= |access-date= May 2, 2013}}</ref>
==See also== {{portal|Biography}} * [[List of Georgetown University alumni]] * [[List of social entrepreneurs]] * [[List of University of Delaware people]] {{clear}}
==References== {{reflist|30em}} * {{cite web|last=Heath|first=Thomas|title=Value Added: The Nonprofit Entrepreneur|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/washbizblog/2009/03/value_added_17.html|work=Washington Post|accessdate=2 May 2013}}

revision.text:
[[File:La lupa con Romolo e Remo di Domenico Parodi e Francesco Biggi (detail).png|thumb|350px|''The She-Wolf with [[Romulus and Remus]]'', sculpture by Francesco Biggi and [[Domenico Parodi]] in the [[Palazzo Rosso (Genoa)|Palazzo Rosso]] of [[Genoa]], Italy]] [[File:Roma, repubblica, moneta di p. satrienus, 77 ac..JPG|thumb|350px|The she-wolf on a coin of the late Roman republic (c.77 BC)]] In the [[Founding of Rome|Roman foundation myth]], it was a '''she-wolf''' that nursed and sheltered the twins [[Romulus and Remus]] after they were abandoned in the wild by order of [[Amulius|King Amulius]] of [[Alba Longa]]. She cared for the infants at her den, a cave known as the [[Lupercal]], until they were discovered by a shepherd, [[Faustulus]]. [[Romulus]] would later become the founder and first king of Rome. The image of the she-wolf suckling the twins has been a symbol of [[Rome]] since ancient times and is one of the most recognizable icons of ancient mythology.<ref> Wiseman ''Remus'' preface pg xiii</ref>
==Origins== There is evidence that the wolf held a special place in the world of the ancient inhabitants of Italy. One legend claims that the [[Hirpini]] people were so-called because, when they set out to found their first colony, they were led to its location by a wolf (from the Sabine word for wolf: ''hirpus'').<ref> Strabo Book V Ch.12 (''Loeb'' pg.467) </ref> The tale of the Lupercal is central to that of the twins, and probably predates theirs. To the Roman god [[Mars (mythology)|Mars]] the wolf is a sacred animal. There is an ongoing debate about a connection to the ancient Roman festival of the [[Lupercalia]].
In [[Greek mythology]], [[Apollo]]'s mother [[Leto]] is reported to have given birth to him as a she-wolf, to evade [[Hera]].<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Aristotle]]|accessdate=5 December 2016|title=History of Animals|url=https://www.loebclassics.com/view/aristotle-history_animals/1965/pb_LCL438.345.xml?rskey=9mJ3UR&result=1&mainRsKey=S0vjOz|doi=10.4159/DLCL.aristotle-history_animals.1965}} {{Subscription needed|via=[[Loeb Classical Library|digital Loeb Classical Library]]}}</ref>
==Literary sources== The 3 "canonical" versions of the myth--those of [[Livy]], [[Plutarch]] and [[Dionysius of Halicarnassus]]--all draw heavily on [[Quintus Fabius Pictor]].<ref> Dionysius I 79</ref> He is considered one of Rome's earliest historians and his now lost work describes the she-wolf and her episode with the twins. The twins were abandoned at the order of Amulius. Some tales claim that they were to be left along the riverbank, others that they were to be cast into the water. The servant charged with the task either thought better of it, or could not get close enough to do the deed because of the flooding. Instead, he left them in the standing water that had formed at the foot of [[Palatine Hill]]. The twins were found either after their basket had been left at the foot of the fig tree, or came to rest there after floating in the water. In each case, the she-wolf rescued them and gently cared for them in or near the Lupercal. Later, they were discovered by local shepherds.
Dionysius reports that rains had raised the water level such that when Amulius' servant arrived at the appointed spot (around a dozen miles from Alba Longa), they left the twins in the floodwaters because they couldn't go any further. The basket they were in floated along until the waters receded and it struck a stone, tossing them out into the mud. The she-wolf arrived and lowered her teats to the crying babes and licked them clean of the mud.
After a shepherd happened upon the scene in the course of tending his flock, he ran to tell his companions, and a group gathered to witness the remarkable sight. The twins were clinging to her as she was their true mother. The she-wolf was nonplussed when the men began making a ruckus to scare her off. She withdrew into a cave that was sacred to the [[Arcadia (ancient region)|Greek colonists]] who had formerly lived in the area and held an altar to the nature god [[Pan (mythology)|Pan]].<ref> Dionysius I ch.79</ref>
Livy claims that the servants of Amulius dropped the twins in the standing water out of simple laziness. The fig tree just happened to be the first spot they came to and they figured the twins would drown no matter what. The twins cried in their basket until the waters receded and left them back on land. The she-wolf arrived from the hills looking for a drink of water when she heard their cries.<ref> Livy I pp.17-19</ref>
The servant was too afraid of the torrential waters to fully carry out the king's orders, according to Plutarch. After being left on the bank, the waters rose further and swept the twins away. It gently carried them along and then dropped them at the fig tree.<ref> Plutarch ''Romulus'' IV pp.99</ref>
The three relay accounts wherein the term "lupa" refers not to a she-wolf, but is a slang word for prostitute. Plutarch tells two other stories not involving the she-wolf or abandonment. In one, the twins are fathered by [[Hercules]] after he wins a dice game. Their mother is the unwitting "prize". In another, the twins are switched at birth by their grandfather for a different pair of infants and secreted out of the city to be raised by shepherds and later, educated in nearby [[Gabii]].<ref> Plutarch ''Romulus'' IV pp.101-105</ref>
==Iconography== [[File:Scan of Figurehead from Geschichte der Kunst des Alterhums band 1 (1776).png|thumb|right|Figurehead from the title page of ''Geschichte der Kunst des Alterhums'' Vol. 1 (1776) by [[Johann Joachim Winckelmann]]. Winckelmann was a pioneer in the study of Graeco-Roman art and [[ancient Roman art]] in particular. He is center, with the she-wolf suckling the twins and [[Homer]] closest to him. The [[Sphinx]] and an [[Etruscan art|Etruscan vase]] are in the background.]]
===Earliest representation=== The "Bolsena Mirror" features a depiction of the she-wolf and the twins surrounded by human and animal figures. Differences in interpretation have precluded virtually any consensus regarding many of its features.<ref> Mazzoni pp173-178</ref> This includes its age. However, it is consistent with other such mirrors, made as bridal gifts, in 4th century BC Euritria, perhaps circa 330-340. The famous [[Capitoline Wolf]] may be of [[Etruscan civilization|Etruscan]] or [[Latins (Italic tribe)|Old Latin]] origin.<ref> Tennant p.81</ref> But, a discovery during its restoration in 2000 and [[radiocarbon dating]] has cast doubt on an ancient origin.<ref name="laregina2006">Adriano La Regina,"[http://www.repubblica.it/2006/11/sezioni/spettacoli_e_cultura/lupa-scultura-roma/lupa-scultura-roma/lupa-scultura-roma.html ''Roma, l'inganno della Lupa è "nata" nel Medioevo]'' "Rome: the phony She-Wolf wasn't born until the Middle-ages" La Republica. 17 November 2006, accessed 1 December 2016</ref> A [[stele]] from [[Bologna]], dated to between 350-400 BC, depicts an animal, possibly a wolf, nursing a single infant. By 269 BC, the silver [[drachm|didrachm]] is the earliest depiction of the complete icon, with the characteristic "turning of the she-wolf's head" backward and downward at the twins.<ref>Rissanen p.336</ref>
The distinctive imagery of the she-wolf and the twins made it more recognizable than other symbols of the city, such as [[Roma (mythology)|Roma]], the patron deity of the city, or the [[Aquila (Roman)|Roman eagle]]. That was useful as the Roman world expanded and symbols of Rome became more important in maintaining unity.<ref>Rissanen p.336</ref> By the 1st century AD, the she-wolf was common in both Rome and the provinces. She and the twins were featured on the elaborate [[Ara Pacis]], built in honor of [[Augustus]] and dedicated to [[Pax (goddess)|Pax]], the goddess of peace.<ref> Rissanen p.336-8</ref>
Coins with their depiction were minted and widely circulated. They were also produced in Roman Colonies as a way to express their own "Roman-ness".<ref> Rissanen p.339</ref> They have been found on personal items such as swords, buckles, lamps and statuettes as well as monuments, mosaic floors and funerary stones that date from the 1st through the 3rd centuries AD.<ref> Rissanen p.343-7</ref>
<gallery heights= 180px widths= "180px" perrow="5"> File:Bolsena mirror Roscher Lexikon p1465.jpg|The controversial Mirror of Bolsena. File:Cr 20-1-Reverse.jpg|Romulus and Remus. An early silver didrachm (6.44 g). c. 269–266 BC<ref name="Crawford">{{citation|last=Crawford|first=Michael Hewson|title=Coinage and Money Under the Roman Republic: Italy and the Mediterranean Economy|page=31|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=84_G_8q6WQcC|accessdate=30 November 2016|year=1985|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-05506-3}}</ref> File:She-wolf suckles Romulus and Remus.jpg|[[Capitoline Wolf]]. Its ancient origin is now in doubt. </gallery>
===Early middle ages=== The [[Franks Casket]], an ornately carved, [[Anglo-Saxon]] chest from the 8th–9th century, probably crafted in a monastery in Northern France, features the she-wolf and twins, along with a [[Rune|Runic]] account of the lupercal.<ref>Rassanen pg.356 fn.148</ref> Other Anglo-Saxon [[Undley bracteate|artifacts]] and coins from the same period also feature them.<ref>Rassanen pg.357</ref> The [[Byzantine]]s continued to use the image, and coins attributed to them have been found in various locations in [[central Asia]] at sites located in modern [[Tadjikistan]] and [[Uzbekistan]] along with an 8th-century [[Sogdiana|Sogdian]] painted mural with a she-wolf, head turned back and down, suckling two infants.<ref>Compareti p.304</ref>
===Sports=== The Italian [[:Association football|football clubs]] [[A.S. Roma]]<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=5 December 2016|title=Official Website of Associazione Sportiva Roma|url=http://www.asroma.com/en}}</ref> and [[S.S. Robur Siena]]<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=5 December 2016|title=Robur Siena|url=http://robursiena.it/}}</ref> use the imagery in their respective team logos.
===Mussolini=== The Fascist government of [[Benito Mussolini]] made use of the she-wolf while in power.
===Coats of arms and emblems=== <gallery heights= 180px widths= "180px" perrow="5"> File:Blason Es famille Ariño (Navarre).svg|The coat of arms of the [[Basques|Basque]] Family Ariño of [[Navarre]]<ref name="SVN-3">''El Solar Vasco-Navarro'', A. et A. Garcia Caraffa, 6 vol. San Sebastian, 1966–1967</ref> File:Blason Es famille Artolaguirre (Donostia).svg|The coat of arms of the [[Basques|Basque]] Family Artolaguirre of [[San Sebastián|Donostia]]<ref name="SVN-3" /> File:CoA mil ITA grp artiglieria 009.png|CoA mil ITA grp artiglieria 009{{cn|date=December 2016}} File:Blason Caudebec-lès-Elbeuf.svg|The coat of arms of the [[Communes of France|Commune]] of [[Caudebec-lès-Elbeuf]], [[Normandy]], France<ref>{{GASOref|76165}}</ref> File:Actual Cluj county CoA.png|The coat of arms of [[Cluj County]], Romania<ref>{{cite web|title=Cluj County Council|url=http://www.cjcluj.ro/|accessdate=5 December 2016}}</ref> File:Stemma-Codogno-Italy.JPG|The coat of arms of the city of [[Codogno]], [[Lombardy]] Italy, featuring the she-wolf leashed to a tree<ref>{{cite web|title=Home Page of the Official Site of the Commune of Codogno|url=http://www.comune.codogno.lo.it/home.html|accessdate=5 December 2016}}</ref> File:Blason Antoine Dubois (1756-1837).svg|The emblem of [[surgeon]] and [[obstetrician]] to [[Napoleon]], [[Nobility of the First French Empire|Baron]] [[Antoine Dubois]], (1756–1837){{cn|date=December 2016}} File:Blason Estillac.svg|The coat of arms of the [[Communes of France|Commune]] of [[Estillac]], [[Nouvelle-Aquitaine]], France<ref>{{cite web|title=Discover the history|url=http://ville-estillac.fr/page/son-histoire|accessdate=5 December 2016}}</ref> File:CoA mil ITA rgt fanteria 080.png|CoA mil ITA rgt fanteria 080 File:CommunesBelgique-La-Louviere.svg|The coat of arms of [[La Louviere]], [[Wallonia]], [[Belgium]] File:Interbelic Nasaud County CoA.png|The coat of arms of [[Năsăud County]], Romania File:Antico Stemma Piacenza.jpg|The ancient coat of arms of the city of [[Piacenza]], [[Emilia-Romagna]], Italy File:CoA mil ITA rgt genio 08.png|CoA mil ITA rgt genio 08 File:La lupa municipale 051214-01.JPG|Emblem of the Capital Police of the Municipality of Rome<ref>{{cite web|title=Local Police Force of Rome|url=https://www.comune.roma.it/pcr/it/dip_polizia_mun_hp.page|accessdate=6 December 2016}}</ref> File:Blason ville Rome-Empire.svg|Reconstruction of the coat of arms of Rome under [[Napoleon]] File:CoA mil ITA scuola genio.png|CoA mil ITA scuola genio File:CoA mil ITA scuola trasmissioni.png|The emblem of the Italian Army Signal School File:Blason ville fr Villeloin-Coulangé (Indre-et-Loire).svg|The coat of arms of the [[Communes of France|Commune]] of [[Villeloin-Coulangé]], [[Centre-Val de Loire]], France </gallery>
===Siena She-Wolf=== The [[Siena|Sienese]] have a traditional tale that the city was founded by [[Senius and Aschius]], another pair of twins who were also suckled by a she-wolf. They were the sons of Remus and fled Rome after his death at the hands of their uncle Romulus. The legend cannot be attested to prior to the Renaissance. However, depictions of a she-wolf and twins are common in the city and some can be dated earlier. <gallery heights= 180px widths= "180px" perrow="5"> File:Toscana Siena6 tango7174.jpg|''Ruota della Fortuna'' "The Wheel of Fortune" is the Centerpiece of the mosaic inlaid floor of the [[Siena Cathedral]] (c.1372) </gallery>
===Notes and coins=== The she-wolf and twins appeared on what may have been the earliest silver coin ever minted in Rome.<ref name="Crawford"/> <gallery heights= 180px widths= "180px" perrow="5"> File:Sextans 2710029.jpg|Sextans from c.215 BC File:Satriena1.jpg|The she-wolf on a coin from c.77 BC With the head of Mars on the other side. File:Romania LeuBanknote 1915.jpg|1 [[Romanian leu]] banknote, 1915. </gallery>
==Lupercalia== The [[Lupercalia]] was a very ancient festival even during Roman times. Roman historians speculated as to its origins. It may be associated with the god [[Lupercus]], the god of [[Pastoralism|shepherds]] and protector of flocks. Some historians link it to the she-wolf and the Lupercal.
==Depictions in art== [[File:Tevere - le lupe a Tevere 07.JPG|thumb|The she-wolf on the embankments of the Tiber]]
===Late antiquity=== <gallery heights= 180px widths= "180px" perrow="5"> File:Mosaic depicting the She-wolf with Romulus and Remus, from Aldborough, about 300-400 AD, Leeds City Museum (16025914306).jpg|Mosaic depicting the She-wolf with Romulus and Remus, from Aldborough (c.300 AD), Leeds City Museum (16025914306) </gallery>
===Middle ages=== <gallery heights= 180px widths= "180px" perrow="5"> File:Perugia - Fontana Maggiore - 6 - La lupa e la Vestale (copie) - Foto G. Dall'Orto 5 ago 2006.jpg|Replica of ''Fontana Maggiore'' of Perugia, [[Nicola Pisano|Nocolai]] and [[Giovanni Pisano|Giovanni]] Pisano (1275), photo by G. Dall'Orto (August 5, 2006) File:Romulus and Remus - British Library Royal MS 19 E v f32r (detail).jpg|From ''Romuleon'', an illuminated manuscript (British Library (1480) </gallery>
===Renaissance=== <gallery heights= 180px widths= "180px" perrow="5"> File:Peter Paul Rubens - Romulus and Remus - Google Art Project.jpg|''Romulus and Remus'', [[Peter Paul Rubens]] (1616) File:Wenceslas Hollar - Romulus and Remus, after Giulio Romano.jpg|''Romulus and Remus'' [[Wenceslas Hollar]] after [[Giulio Romano]], (16c.) File:Quattro Fontane - The River Tiber.jpg|''The River Tiber'' from the [[Quattro Fontane]] by [[Muzio Mattei]] and [[Domenico Fontana]] (late 16c.). The she-wolf can be see peeking from behind [[Father Tiber]] on the right. </gallery>
===18th-20th Centuries=== <gallery heights= 180px widths= "180px" perrow="5"> File:La lupa con Romolo e Remo di Domenico Parodi e Francesco Biggi.JPG|''La lupa con Romolo e Remo'' "The She-Wolf with Romulus and Remus", [[Domenico Parodi]] and Francesco Biggi (1874) File:Rome Liddell 1860 Lupa Capitolina.jpg|Scanned from "History of Rome", published 1860, by Henry Liddell (6 February 1811 – 18 January 1898) with illustrations provided by Sir John Gardner Wilkinson (5 October 1797–29 October 1875). Scanned by Man vyi File:David Ozeransky from Ten Tribes (1932).jpg|''Romulus and Remus'' from Ten Tribes, sculptor: [[Eric Gill]], photo by David Ozeransky (1932) File:Comic History of Rome Table 01 Romulus and Remus discovered by a gentle shepherd.jpg|''Comic History of Rome Table 01'', featuring a matronly she-wolf and [[Picus]], the woodpecker overhead. [[John Leech (caricaturist)|John Leech]] (c.1850) </gallery>

Library|digital Loeb Classical Library]]}} *{{cite book|last=Mazzoni|first=Cristina|title=She-Wolf: The Story of a Roman Icon|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4cq1XH0L3GUC|accessdate=2 December 2016|title=Geography, Volume I Books 1-2|url=http://www.loebclassics.com/view/LCL049/1917/volume.xml|doi=10.4159/DLCL.strabo-geography.1917}} {{Subscription needed|via=[[Loeb Classical Library|digital ===Notes=== {{Reflist|30em}}
[[Category:8th century BC in the Roman Kingdom]] [[Category:Female legendary creatures]] [[Category:Female mammals]] [[Category:Roman mythology]] [[Category:Wolves in folklore, religion and mythology]] [[Category:She-wolf (Roman mythology)| ]] [[Category:Mythological characters]]

{{Infobox musical artist | name = Staff Benda Bilili | image = Staff-benda-belili-2010-ffm-010.jpg | image_size = | landscape = | alt = | caption = 2010 at "Palmengarten" in [[Frankfurt am Main]] | background = group_or_band | alias = | origin = [[Kinshasa]], [[DR Congo]] | genre = | years_active ={{start date|2005}}––present | label = [[Crammed Discs]] | associated_acts = [[Mbongwana Star]] | website = | current_members = Ricky Likabu
Roger Landu | past_members = Coco Ngambali
Théo Nzonza | module = | module2 = | module3 = }} '''Staff Benda Bilili''' are a group of street musicians in the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]]. They used to live around the grounds of the zoo in the country's capital city, [[Kinshasa]], and play music which is rooted in [[soukous]], with elements of old-school [[rhythm and blues]] and [[reggae]]. The core of the band consists of four senior singers/guitarists, who are [[Paraplegia|paraplegic]] (they had [[poliomyelitis]] when they were young) and move around in spectacularly customized [[tricycle]]s. They are backed by a younger rhythm section consisting of abandoned street children who were taken under the protection of the older members of the band. The soloist is an 18-year-old boy (2009) who plays guitar-like solos on an electrified one-stringed [[lute]] he designed and built himself out of a tin can. The group's name translates roughly from [[Lingala language|Lingala]] as "look beyond appearances".{{cite news |last=Smith |first=Caspar Llewellyn |title=From Kinshasa to your town: the incredible rise of Staff Benda Bilili |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/nov/01/staff-benda-bilili-congo-interview |work=The Guardian |date=1 November 2009 |accessdate=1 November 2009 |location=London}} Staff Benda Bilili earned the 2009 Artist Award at [[Womex]] (World Music Expo).{{cite web |title=WOMEX 09 Award for Artists: WOMEX is proud to announce the winners... Staff Benda Bilili (DR Congo) |url=http://www.womex.com/realwomex/award1.html |publisher=WOMEX |accessdate=1 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100801063903/http://www.womex.com/realwomex/award1.html |archivedate=1 August 2010 |df= }} The group has sought to raise awareness about crimes against humanity in [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]], contributing to the [[Enough Project]] and [[Downtown Records]]' Raise Hope for Congo compilation.[http://raisehopeforcongomusic.org/ Raise Hope for Congo] ==Background== Staff Benda Bilili was formed by Ricky Likabu and Coco Ngambali with other paraplegic musicians, as other bands in Kinshasa would not work with them. They were later joined by a teenager, Roger Landu, who fashioned his own instrument - named a ''satongé'' - from an empty fish can, a piece of wood and a guitar string.{{cite news |last=Denselow |first=Robin |title=Staff Benda Bilili, Africa's unlikely pop stars |url=http://newsvote.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/newsnight/8369900.stm |work=BBC News |date=21 November 2009 |accessdate=22 November 2009}}{{cite web |title=Staff Benda Bilili|publisher=BBC, London |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/proms/whats-on/2012/september-06/14338/programme-notes |accessdate=11 September 2012}} The band rehearsed in Kinshasa zoo, because it was a quiet location, and played the streets of Kinshasa until they were heard by [[Vincent Kenis]], a Belgian record producer specialising in Congolese music, who arranged for the band to record their debut album, ''Tres Tres Fort'' ("Very Very Strong"). ==The "voting song"== In 2006, Staff Benda Bilili's song "Let's Go and Vote" ("Allons Voter"), written and performed by the musicians, was played repeatedly in the run-up to the 2006 historic polls on radio and television stations; it was reported to be responsible for a 70% increase in voter turnout. The credits on the video clip say it was produced by Monuc [[UN Mission in DR Congo]] and distributed by the UN Development Programme (UNDP). The musicians were not offered contracts, but were reportedly paid $50 each. Staff Benda Bilili filed a lawsuit in the Congolese courts seeking $100,000 for Monuc's use of their music.{{cite news |last=Zajtman |first=Arnaud |title=Disabled Congo singers to sue UN |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/6612749.stm |work=BBC News |date=2 May 2007 |accessdate=1 November 2009}} == The videos and the film == Staff Benda Bilili were featured in the documentary film ''Jupiter's Dance'', which follows the story of [[Jupiter Bokondji]], a musician who is also involved in Staff Benda Bilili. The film was produced by [[Renaud Barret]] and [[Florent de la Tullaye]] (aka [[Belle Kinoise]]), who have been documenting the band's progress since 2005. They shot several videos, which have become quite popular on the Internet.Andy Morgan, [https://www.theguardian.com/music/2012/aug/26/jupiter-bokondji-africa-express-congo Jupiter Bokondji: 'The cultural riches of Congo are immense'], The Guardian, 26 August 2012. Barret and de la Tullaye directed a feature-length documentary on the band, ''[[Benda Bilili!]]'' The film was selected by the Quinzaine des Réalisateurs (Directors' Fortnight) at the 2010 edition of the Cannes Film Festival, and premiered on May 13, 2010, with the group in attendance and performing at the opening of the Quinzaine.{{cite news|last=Hochman|first=Steve|title='Benda Bilili!' documentary details the band's difficult lives|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/oct/05/entertainment/la-et-1005-staff-benda-bilili-20111005|accessdate=17 March 2012|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=5 October 2011}} == Career== Entitled ''Très Très Fort'', the band's debut album was released on [[Crammed Discs]] in March 2009. It was produced over the course of three years by Crammed's [[Vincent Kenis]] (known for introducing and producing bands such as [[Konono Nº1]], [[Kasai Allstars]], and for the [[Congotronics series]]). Kenis recorded the band mostly in the Kinshasa zoo. The album also contains four of Barret & de la Tullaye's videos.{{cite web|title=Staff Benda Bilili 'Très Très Fort' |publisher=Crammed |url=http://www.crammed.be/craworld/crw51/index.htm |accessdate=1 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090309184642/http://www.crammed.be/craworld/crw51/index.htm |archivedate=March 9, 2009 }} Staff Benda Bilili's ''Très Très Fort'' album was also be released on vinyl by Crammed Discs in 2010, only as part of the limited-edition Congotronics Vinyl Box Set which includes most albums on the [[Congotronics series]]. Media reactions to ''Très Très Fort'' were excellent, especially in the UK,{{cite news |last=Lais |first=Johnny |title=Staff Benda Bilili Tres Tres Fort Review |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/reviews/cnp2 |work=BBC |date=20 March 2009 |accessdate=1 November 2009 |quote=The explosive debut album from Staff Benda Bilili is perhaps an example of African street music at its finest.}}{{cite news |title=The 20 best new acts of 2009 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/jan/18/best-new-acts-2009 |work=The Observer |date=18 January 2009 |accessdate=1 November 2009 |location=London}}{{cite news |title=Staff Benda Bilili - The masters of survival, the sound of the ghetto |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/staff-benda-bilili--the-masters-of-survival-the-sound-of-the-ghetto-1607949.html |work=The Independent |date=13 February 2009 |accessdate=1 November 2009 |location=London}} the US,{{cite news |last=Zupko |first=Sarah |title=Staff Benda Bilili - "Polio" |url=http://www.popmatters.com/pm/post/69721-staff-benda-bilili-polio/ |work=Popmatters |date=29 January 2009 |accessdate=1 November 2009}} and France.{{cite news |title=Benda Bilili, perles musicales des rues de Kinshasa |url=http://africamix.blog.lemonde.fr/2009/02/25/benda-bilili-perles-musicales-des-rues-de-kinshasa/ |work=Le Monde |date=25 February 2009 |accessdate=1 November 2009 |language=French |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721005530/http://africamix.blog.lemonde.fr/2009/02/25/benda-bilili-perles-musicales-des-rues-de-kinshasa/ |archivedate=21 July 2011 |df= }} Staff Benda Bilili have performed extensively around Europe, Japan and Australia, and were to tour the US for the first time in October 2012. Entitled ''Bouger Le Monde'' ('Make The World Move'), Staff Benda Bilili's second album was recorded in Kinshasa and mixed in Brussels, again by producer Vincent Kenis. The album comprises 11 new songs and features lead vocals by seven different band members. It was to be released worldwide by Crammed Discs in September 2012. In February 2013 ''[[The Guardian]]'' reported that singer and songwriter Coco Ngambali had quit, along with fellow vocalist Théo Nzonza, and a tour of top European venues scheduled for March and April had been cancelled amid accusations of mismanagement.{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/feb/15/staff-benda-bilili-where-did-it-go-wrong | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Andy | last=Morgan | title=Staff Benda Bilili: where did it all go so wrong? | date=15 February 2013}} The band played some dates in Europe in the autumn of 2013 and summer of 2014. Ngambali and Nzonza now play in [[Mbongwana Star]].{{cite news|last1=Petredis|first1=Alex|title=Mbongwana Star: From Kinshasa review – thrillingly wrong-footing Congolese music|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/may/14/mbongwana-star-from-kinshasa-review|accessdate=17 December 2015|work=The Guardian|date=14 May 2015}} ==Discography (albums)== * ''Très Très Fort'' (2009, Crammed Discs) * ''Bouger Le Monde'' (2012, Crammed Discs) ==Gallery== 2012.04 benda bilili 03.JPG|Stockholm, 2012 2011-07-01-eurockeennes-23.jpg|Eurockéennes festival, 2011 Staff benda bilili-IMG 5475.jpg|Eurockéennes festival, 2011 2012.04 benda bilili 02.JPG|Stockholm, 2012 2012.04 benda bilili 05.JPG|Stockholm, 2012 2012.04 benda bilili 01.JPG|Stockholm, 2012 2012.04 benda bilili 04.JPG|Stockholm, 2012 == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100220235004/http://crammed.be.dd5126.kasserver.com/index.php?id=34&art_id=146 Staff Benda Bilili page] on the site of the [[Crammed Discs]] label *[https://web.archive.org/web/20091018181555/http://www.womex.com/realwomex/main.php?id_headings=88&id_realwomex=11&subheading=104 Womex Artist Award page] *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/newsnight/8370203.stm Appearance on BBC's ''Newsnight''] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rt-G_6Ba_rk Video preview of Staff Benda Bilili's second album, including footage shot during the rehearsals and recordings in Kinshasa] {{Authority control}} [[Category:Democratic Republic of the Congo musical groups]] [[Category:People with poliomyelitis]]

{{Infobox person | name = Susan Bluestein | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1946|5|27|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[New York, New York]], U.S. | occupation = American casting director | years_active = 1980–present | spouse = [[Brad Davis (actor)|Brad Davis]]
(1976–1991; his death) | children =1}} '''Susan Davis''' ([[Married and maiden names|née]] '''Bluestein'''; born May 27, 1946) is an [[United States|American]] [[casting director]] and the widow of [[actor]] [[Brad Davis (actor)|Brad Davis]]. ==Biography== Born in [[Manhattan]] and raised in [[Queens, New York]], Bluestein has spent much of her career casting [[television movie]]s, including ''[[Jean Harris|The People vs. Jean Harris]]'', ''[[A Piano for Mrs. Cimino]]'', ''[[Casualties of Love: The Long Island Lolita Story]]'', and ''[[Oldest Living Confederate Widow Tells All]]''. She cast multiple episodes of the series ''[[Punky Brewster]]'', ''[[Providence (TV series)|Providence]]'' and ''[[JAG (TV series)|JAG]]'' and has cast every episode of ''[[NCIS (TV series)|NCIS]]'' and ''[[NCIS: Los Angeles]]'' since their premieres. In 1995, she won the Emmy Award for Outstanding Individual Achievement in Casting for her work on ''[[NYPD Blue]]''.{{IMDb name|0089578}} Bluestein's [[feature film]] casting credits include ''[[Crimes of the Heart (film)|Crimes of the Heart]]'', ''[[Who's Harry Crumb?]]'', and ''[[Homeward Bound: The Incredible Journey]]''. Other recent projects are the 2008 [[BBC]]/[[HBO]] [[docudrama]] ''[[House of Saddam]]'' and ''[[Dilli 6]]''. ==Family== Bluestein and Davis were married in 1976 and had one child, Alex, a [[trans man|transgender man]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sheilaomalley.com/?p=33534 |title=Feb. 19/20 at The Knitting Factory: Alex Davis: Man of the Year | The Sheila Variations |website=Sheilaomalley.com |date=2011-02-17 |accessdate=2017-04-18}} In 1985, Davis was diagnosed [[HIV]]-positive, a condition the couple kept secret until just prior to his death by [[euthanasia|assisted suicide]] in 1991.Alex Witchel, [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?sec=health&res=950CE2DF143FF935A25757C0A961958260 "For the Widow Of Brad Davis, Time Cannot Heal All the Wounds"], ''New York Times'', April 16, 1997. Shortly after his death she co-authored a [[memoir]], ''After Midnight: The Life and Death of Brad Davis'' with Hilary De Vries. ==Casting filmography== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! {{Orphan|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox fashion designer |image= |caption= |name=Teona Gardapkhadze
{{nobold|თეო გარდაფხაძე}} |nationality=[[Georgians|Georgian]] |birth_date= {{Birth date and age|1983|08|17|df=yes}} |birth_place= [[Tbilisi]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] |death_date= |death_place= |education= [[Tbilisi State Academy of Arts]] |label_name= TEYÓ |significant_design= |spouse = |children = |awards=}} '''Teona Gardapkhadze''' ({{lang-ka|თეო გარდაფხაძე}}) known as '''TEYÓ''' is a [[Georgians|Georgian]] [[fashion designer]] based in [[Tbilisi]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]]. She was born in 1983. Teona graduated an Architecture department of [[Tbilisi State Academy of Arts]]. In 2006 she decided to try herself in fashion design. Inspiration + Tendency + Love is a formula of Teona's brand TEYÓ, which was created in 2012. Same year she presented her first f/w collection at Tbilisi Fashion Week. After her debut she successfully works for several stores in [[Azerbaijan]], [[Kazakhstan]] and [[Russia]], as well as in [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tbilisifashionweek.com/teyo/|title=TEYO : Tbilisi Fashion Week|publisher=Tbilisi Fashion Week|language=en|date=2015-01-27}}{{cite web|url=http://www.mbfashionweektbilisi.com/tey-by-teo-gardapkhadze|title=TEYÓ BY TEO GARDAPKHADZE|publisher=Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Tbilisi|language=en}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nargismagazine.az/az/22050|title=TWF: AVTANDIL, DATUNA SULIKASHVILI, TEYO|language=en|date=2014-05-14}} Her clothes are chosen by many celebrities, including [[Sheikha Mozah]]; Ukrainian singer, actress, songwriter, winner of the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2016]] - [[Jamala]]; singer and the current vocalist for the group [[A-Studio]] - [[Keti Topuria]]; Russian journalist [[:ru:Хромченко, Эвелина Леонидовна|Evelina Khromtchenko]] and others.{{cite web|url=http://www.yapokupayu.ru/blogs/post/otkrytie-kornera-teyo-by-teo-gardaphadze-na-fabrike|title=В Самаре откроется корнер Teyo by Teo Gardapkhadze|language=ru}} == References == {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gardapkhadze, Teona}} [[Category:1983 births]] [[Category:People from Georgia (country)]] [[Category:Fashion designers from Georgia (country)]] [[Category:Tbilisi State Academy of Arts alumni]] [[Category:Living people]]

{{Other people|Tony Martin}} {{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} '''Anthony Edward Martin''' (born 16 December 1944)<ref>{{cite news|last=Foggo|first=Daniel|title=Season's greetings from Tony Martin|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1449985/Seasons-greetings-from-Tony-Martin.html|accessdate=3 April 2012|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=21 December 2003|location=London|quote=As he approaches his 59th birthday later this month,…}}</ref> is a farmer from [[Norfolk]], [[England]], who shot a [[burglary in English law|burglar]] dead in his home in August 1999. Martin was convicted of [[Murder in English law|murder]], later reduced to [[manslaughter]] on grounds of [[diminished responsibility]], and served three years in prison, having been denied [[parole]]. He has since lived at a secret address.
== Burglary and shooting ==
On 20 August 1999, Tony Martin, a bachelor, was living alone at his farmhouse, Bleak House, in [[Emneth Hungate]], [[Norfolk]] which he inherited from his uncle in about 1980.<ref>[[Real Crime]], [[ITV1]]</ref> He claimed to have been burgled a total of ten times, losing £6,000 worth of furniture. Police sources say they are not sure that all the incidents took place.<ref name="Gillan">{{cite news|last=Gillan|first=Audrey|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2000/apr/20/tonymartin.ukcrime2|title=Bleak world of the loner who killed|date=20 April 2000|accessdate=6 November 2015}}</ref> Martin also complained about police inaction over the burglaries and claimed that multiple items and furniture were stolen such as dinnerware and a grandfather clock.<ref name="Gillan"/> Martin had equipped himself with an illegally held [[pump-action]] [[Winchester Model 1300]] 12 gauge<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/tony-martin-free-in-a-year-6299321.html|title=Tony Martin free in a year|publisher=}}</ref> [[shotgun]] which he claimed to have found. [[Firearms (Amendment) Act 1988|Changes in legislation in 1988]], resulting from the [[Hungerford massacre]], had changed the licensing treatment of semi-automatic and pump-action shotguns with a magazine capacity of more than two to equate to that of a firearm, requiring a valid firearms certificate.<ref>[[Shotgun#Legal issues]]</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2001/oct/30/tonymartin.ukcrime2 | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Steven | last=Morris | title=The killer who won a nation's sympathy | date=30 October 2001}}</ref> Martin had his shotgun certificate revoked in 1994 after he found a man stealing apples in his orchard and shot a hole in the back of his vehicle.<ref name="guardian.co.uk">{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2000/apr/20/tonymartin.ukcrime2 | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Audrey | last=Gillan | title=Bleak world of the loner who killed | date=26 April 2000}}</ref>
On the evening of 20 August 1999, two burglars – [[Brendon Fearon]], 29, and 16-year-old Fred Barras, both [[Irish Travellers]] from [[Newark-on-Trent]], [[Nottinghamshire]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/11044022/Tony-Martin-15-years-on-I-dont-want-to-go-back-there-because-it-could-happen-again.html|title=Tony Martin, 15 years on: I don't want to go back there because it could happen again|first=Claire|last=Duffin|date=19 August 2014|publisher=|via=www.telegraph.co.uk}}</ref> – broke into Martin's house.<ref name="timeline">{{cite news|title=Timeline: The Tony Martin case|work=[[BBC News]]|date=28 July 2003|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/norfolk/3087003.stm|accessdate=13 February 2007}}</ref> Shooting downwards in the dark with his shotgun loaded with [[birdshot]], Martin shot three times towards the intruders (once when they were in the stairwell and twice more when they were trying to flee through the window of an adjacent ground floor room). Barras was hit in the back and both sustained gunshot injuries to their legs. Both escaped through the window but Barras died at the scene.<ref name="TMCC">{{cite news|title=Tony Martin: Crime and controversy|work=[[BBC News]]|date=13 June 2003|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/norfolk/3009769.stm|accessdate=13 February 2007}}</ref> Martin claimed that he opened fire after being woken when the intruders smashed a window. The prosecution accused him of lying in wait for the burglars and opening fire without warning from close range, in retribution for previous break-ins at his home.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1361023/Killer-who-was-a-hero-to-victims-of-crime.html | work=The Telegraph | location=London | first=Richard | last=Alleyne | title=Killer who was a hero to victims of crime | date=31 October 2001}}</ref>
On 10 January 2000, Fearon and Darren Bark, 33 (who had acted as the [[crime scene getaway|getaway driver]]), both from Newark-on-Trent, admitted to conspiring to burgle Martin's farmhouse. Fearon was sentenced to 36 months in prison, and Bark to 30 months<ref name="timeline" /> (with an additional 12 months arising from previous offences). Fearon was released on 10 August 2001.<ref name="timeline" /> Fred Barras, the dead youth, had already been convicted of a total of 29 offences by the time of his death at the age of 16, including seven convictions for theft and six for fraud.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/719895.stm|title=BBC News - UK - Burglars were experienced criminals|website=news.bbc.co.uk}}</ref> He had been sentenced to two months in a young offenders' institution for assaulting a policeman, theft and being drunk and disorderly. On the night he was killed, Barras had just been released on bail after being accused of stealing garden furniture. His elderly grandmother, Mary Dolan, stated: "It's not fair that the farmer has got all the money and he is the one that took Fred away."<ref name="independent">{{cite news|title=Burglar's family set to sue Martin|work=The Independent|accessdate=5 February 2011|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/this-britain/burglars-family-set-to-sue-martin-710851.html|first=Damien|last=Brook|date=7 August 2000|location=London}}</ref>
== Murder trial ==
On 23 August 1999, Martin was charged with the murder of Barras, the [[attempted murder]] of Fearon, "wounding with intent to cause injury" to Fearon and "possessing a firearm with intent to endanger life".<ref name="timeline" /> Martin did not hold a valid [[Gun politics in the United Kingdom#Licensing and legislation|shotgun certificate]] (licence), let alone the more restrictive Firearms Certificate he would have needed to possess the Winchester pump-action shotgun that held a maximum of five rounds.
English law permits a person to kill another in self-defence only if the person defending him or herself uses no more than "reasonable force"; it is the responsibility of the jury to determine whether or not an unreasonable amount of force was used.<ref>{{cite book|author=Michael T. W. Arnheim|title=The handbook of human rights law: an accessible approach to the issues and principles|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=d1PEzuvPno0C|year=2004|publisher=Kogan Page yarite Publishers|isbn=978-0-7494-3498-4|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=d1PEzuvPno0C&pg=PA88 88], [https://books.google.com/books?id=d1PEzuvPno0C&pg=PA205 205]|ref=harv}}</ref> The jury at the [[trial (law)|trial]] were told that they had the option of returning a verdict of [[manslaughter]] rather than murder, if they thought that Martin "did not intend to kill or cause serious bodily harm".<ref>{{cite news|title=A victim, not a hero|work=The Guardian|date=29 July 2003|url=https://www.theguardian.com/martin/article/0,,1007693,00.html|accessdate=14 February 2007|location=London}}</ref> However, the jurors found Martin guilty of murder by a 10 to 2 majority.<ref>{{cite news|title=Farmer guilty of murdering burglar|work=BBC News|date=20 April 2000|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/717511.stm|accessdate=13 February 2007}}</ref>
He was sentenced to [[Life imprisonment in England and Wales|life imprisonment]], with a recommended minimum term to serve of 9 years, reduced to 8 years by the Lord Chief Justice.
== Appeal ==
An appeal was considered in October 2001 by three senior judges headed by [[Harry Woolf, Baron Woolf|Lord Woolf LCJ]]. Submissions by the defence that Martin had fired in his own defence were rejected by the appeal court. On this occasion, the defence also submitted evidence that Martin was diagnosed with [[paranoid personality disorder]] exacerbated by depression<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1382255/Tony-Martin-is-told-that-he-cannot-appeal-to-Lords.html|title=Tony Martin is told that he cannot appeal to Lords|first=Joshua Rozenberg, Legal|last=Editor|date=29 January 2018|publisher=|via=www.telegraph.co.uk}}</ref> and that his paranoia was specifically directed at anyone intruding into his home; he was also diagnosed with [[Asperger syndrome]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Turney|first=Bob|year=2005|title=Wanted!|publisher=Waterside Press|isbn=978-1-906-53464-6|page=60}}</ref> This submission was accepted by the Court of Appeal and, on the grounds of [[diminished responsibility]], Martin's murder conviction was replaced by manslaughter carrying a five-year sentence, and his ten-year sentence for wounding Fearon was reduced to three years. These sentences were to run concurrently.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWCA/Crim/2001/2245.html|title=Court of Appeal, Law Report|publisher=}}</ref>
== Parole applications and release ==
Martin was imprisoned in [[Highpoint South (HM Prison)|Highpoint Prison]] at [[Stradishall]] in Suffolk. When he became eligible for parole and early release in January 2003, the [[Parole Board]] rejected his application without stating a reason.<ref>{{cite news|title=Martin's parole bid fails|work=[[BBC News]]|date=16 January 2003|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/2662181.stm|accessdate=13 February 2007}}</ref> The chairman of the parole board, Sir [[David Hatch]], in an interview with ''[[The Times]]'' described Martin as "a very dangerous man" who might still believe his action had been right.<ref>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article1136392.ece "Tony Martin is a dangerous man, says parole chief"], ''The Times'', 27 May 2003. Retrieved on 16 June 2007</ref>
Martin challenged the decision in the High Court, where the parole board's decision was upheld.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWHC/Admin/2003/1512.html|title= [2003] EWHC 1512 (Admin)|publisher=[[British and Irish Legal Information Institute]]}}</ref> Probation officers on Martin's cases said there was an "unacceptable risk" that Martin might again react with excessive force if other would-be burglars intruded on his Norfolk farm.<ref>{{cite news|title=Martin loses parole appeal|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=8 May 2003|url=https://www.theguardian.com/martin/article/0,,951953,00.html|accessdate=13 February 2007|location=London}}</ref> On 28 July 2003, Martin was released after serving three years of his five-year sentence,<ref name="timeline" /> the maximum period for which he could be held following good behaviour.
== Compensation claim ==
During 2003, Fearon applied for, and received, an estimated £5,000 of [[legal aid]] to sue Martin for loss of earnings due to the injuries he had sustained.<ref>{{cite news|last=Morris|first=Steven|title=Legal aid for burglar shot by Tony Martin|work=The Guardian|date=6 June 2002|url=https://www.theguardian.com/martin/article/0,,751000,00.html|accessdate=13 February 2007|location=London}}</ref> However, the case was thrown into doubt when photographs were published in [[The Sun (United Kingdom)|''The Sun'']], showing him "cycling and climbing with little apparent difficulty" suggesting that Fearon's injuries were not as serious as had been claimed.<ref>{{cite news|last=Allison|first=Rebecca|title=Legal action by burglar 'in doubt'|work=The Guardian|date=20 August 2003|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk_news/story/0,,1021965,00.html|accessdate=13 February 2007|location=London}}</ref> While the case was pending, Fearon was recalled to jail after being charged with the theft of a vehicle while on probation on a conviction for dealing heroin.<ref>{{cite news|first=Steven|last=Morris|title=Martin burglar back in custody|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2003/sep/05/tonymartin.ukcrime|work=The Guardian|location=London|date=5 September 2003|accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref> Fearon later dropped the case when Martin agreed to drop a counter-claim. <ref>{{cite news|last=Morris|first=Steven|title=Martin expected to end legal dispute with burglar|work=The Guardian|date=22 September 2003|url=https://www.theguardian.com/martin/article/0,,1046851,00.html|accessdate=13 February 2007|location=London}}</ref>
Nick Makin, Martin's solicitor, said: "It is appalling that the family of someone who has a criminal record for burglary and assault should attempt to claim any damages of criminal injury when he was shot while burgling the dwelling of an innocent person... It is also appalling that they may get legal aid while his victim is in prison and patently unable to work and equally cannot get legal aid... There is something wrong and perverse with our legal system that it permits this."<ref name="independent" />
== Threats, interviews, and political activity ==
The BBC reported in 2003 that Fearon's supporters put a bounty on Martin's head of several tens of thousands of pounds.<ref name="TMCC" /> In July 2003, ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' reported that a cousin of Barras had said that a £60,000 bounty had been put on Martin's head.<ref name=cousin>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1437256/Tony-Martin-is-going-to-get-it-warns-cousin-of-the-boy-he-shot.html|title=Tony Martin is 'going to get it', warns cousin of the boy he shot|author1=Thair Shaikh|author2=Daniel Foggo|date=27 July 2003|publisher=telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=16 October 2010|location=London}}</ref>
In October 2003, the ''[[Daily Mirror]]'' paid Martin £125,000 for an exclusive interview on his release from prison. After investigation, the [[Press Complaints Commission]] ruled that the payment was justified and in the public interest because Martin "had a unique insight into an issue of great public concern".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/payment-to-tony-martin-was-justified-says-pcc-89575.html|title=Payment to Tony Martin was justified, says PCC|author=Ian Burrel|date=3 October 2003|publisher=The Independent|accessdate=16 October 2010|location=London}}</ref>
Since his release Martin has appeared on the platform of the [[UK Independence Party]] (UKIP)<ref>{{cite news|last=Storer|first=Jackie|title=Martin urges 'decency' in politics|work=[[BBC News]]|date=10 October 2003|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/3180820.stm|accessdate=13 February 2007}}</ref> and was the guest-of-honour at the Traditional Britain Group's Annual Dinner at [[Simpson's-in-the-Strand]] in London on 7 November 2003.<ref>''Traditional Britain Newsletter'', Summer 2003, notice p.2</ref> Martin said himself that he had attended meetings of the [[National Front (United Kingdom)|National Front]] in Norfolk, and later went on to endorse the [[British National Party]].<ref name="Foggo">{{cite news|last=Foggo|first=Daniel|title=Vote BNP and give Britain a dictator, says Tony Martin|work=[[Daily Telegraph]]|date=18 April 2004|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1459558/Vote-BNP-and-give-Britain-a-dictator-says-Tony-Martin.html|accessdate=13 February 2007|location=London}}</ref> One of Martin's uncles by marriage, [[Andrew Fountaine]], was a founder member of the National Front.<ref name="Gillan"/><ref name="Foggo"/>
== Recent years == In August 2014, it was revealed that Martin's house had been boarded up since his imprisonment and he had subsequently lived both with friends and in his car.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/11044022/Tony-Martin-15-years-on-I-dont-want-to-go-back-there-because-it-could-happen-again.html|title=Tony Martin, 15 years on: I don't want to go back there because it could happen again|newspaper=Telegraph.co.uk|access-date=2016-11-07}}</ref>
On 31 December 2015, the media reported that Martin had been arrested on suspicion of possessing an illegal firearm.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-35206113 "Tony Martin held over gun possession"] [[BBC News]] 31 December 2015</ref> Martin was not charged.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Norfolk farmer Tony Martin faces no charges over firearms arrest|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-norfolk-35558263|date=12 February 2016|publisher=[[BBC News]]|access-date=29 January 2018}}</ref>
== Books ==
* Martin, T. (with [[John McVicar]] – editor) (2004), ''A Right to Kill? : Tony Martin's Story'', Artnik, {{ISBN|1-903906-36-9}}, {{ISBN|978-1-903906-36-1}}. * Saunders, J. (2001), ''Tony Martin and the Bleak House Tragedy'', True Crime Library/Forum Press, {{ISBN|1-874358-37-0}}, {{ISBN|978-1-874358-37-4}}. * Turney, B. (2005), ''Wanted'', Waterside Press, {{ISBN|1-904380-13-1}}, {{ISBN|978-1-90653-464-6}}.
== See also ==
* [[Castle doctrine]] * [[defense of property|Defence of property]] * [[Joe Horn shooting controversy]] * [[Self-defence in English law]] * [[Death of John Ward]] * [[Munir Hussain and victims' rights]] * ''[[Katko v. Briney]]'' * [[Vincent family]]

{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians --> | name = Tony Renis | image = Tony_Renis_Primo_Piano.jpg | caption = Tony Renis in the 1990s | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Elio Cesari | alias = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1938|5|13}} | birth_place = [[Milan]], Italy | instrument = [[Singing|Vocals]] | genre = [[Adult contemporary]], [[pop music|pop]], [[Vocal music|vocal]] | occupation = Musician, songwriter, record producer | years_active = 1958–2004 | label = Combo Record, [[La voce del padrone]], [[RCA Italiana]]; [[Casa Ricordi|Numero Uno]], [[EMI Italiana]], [[Warner Bros.]], ''et al.'' | associated_acts = | website = }}
'''Tony Renis''' (born May 13, 1938), stage name of '''Elio Cesari''', is an Italian [[singer]], [[composer]], [[songwriter]], [[music producer]] and [[film]] [[actor]].
== Life and career ==
Born in [[Milan]], he debuted in the mid-1950s, paired with [[Adriano Celentano]], performing an impression of [[Dean Martin]] and [[Jerry Lewis]]. In 1958, he signed to the label "Combo Record" as a singer and started releasing covers of Italian and American songs. In 1961, Renis debuted at the [[Sanremo Music Festival]] with the song "Pozzanghere".<ref name=sanr>{{cite book|last=Marcello Giannotti|title=L'enciclopedia di Sanremo|publisher=Gremese Editore, 2005|isbn=88-8440-379-0}}</ref>
In 1962, Renis gained international success with the song "[[Quando, quando, quando]]", written with [[Alberto Testa (lyricist)|Alberto Testa]] and performed at the Sanremo Music Festival.<ref name=sanr/> One year later, he won the same Festival with the song "Una per tutte", and, in 1967, he reached second place with the song "Quando dico che ti amo".<ref name=sanr/>
In 1972, he composed the song "[[Grande grande grande]]" with Alberto Testa, successfully performed by [[Mina (singer)|Mina]], and later by [[Shirley Bassey]] under the English translation title "Never Never Never" also covered by [[Vikki Carr]], [[Celine Dion]] with [[Luciano Pavarotti]], [[Julio Iglesias]], [[Patrizio Buanne]] with [[Renee Olstead]], and others.
In 1974, he won the [[Nastro d'Argento for Best Score|Nastro d'Argento for the Best Score]] for the score of ''[[Brothers Blue]]''.<ref name=premi>{{cite book|last=Enrico Lancia|title=I premi del cinema|publisher=Gremese Editore, 1998|isbn=8877422211}}</ref>
In the 1980s, Tony Renis mainly worked as music producer and, in 1981, he launched the career of [[Nikka Costa]].<ref name=reni>{{cite book|last=Mimma Gaspari|title=Penso che un "mondo" così non ritorni mai più|publisher=Baldini Castoldi Dalai, 2009|isbn=88-6073-469-X}}</ref>
In 1999, Renis received a [[Golden Globe Award]] and was nominated for an [[Academy Awards|Oscar]] for the song "[[The Prayer (Celine Dion and Andrea Bocelli song)|The Prayer]]", performed by [[Celine Dion]] and [[Andrea Bocelli]], from the ''[[Quest for Camelot]]'' movie soundtrack.<ref name=reni/>
In 2005, he won a [[David di Donatello]] for the song "Merry Christmas in Love" from the film ''[[Christmas in Love]]''. The song was also nominated for a Golden Globe for Best Original Song at the [[63rd Golden Globe Awards]].
He received the America Award of the [[Italy-USA Foundation]] in 2016.
== Selected discography == [[File:Tony Sinatra.jpg|thumb|250px|Tony Renis and [[Frank Sinatra]] celebrating a [[Gold record]] in 1985.]]

revision.text:
[[File:William C. Irvine.jpg|thumb|From the frontispiece of "25 Years' Mission Work Among the Lepers of India".]] {{EngvarB|date=May 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} '''William Carleton Irvine''' (3 June 1871 – 5 September 1946), was a [[missionary]], writer and the founding editor of the ''Indian Christian'' magazine.<ref name="Stunt121">{{cite book |last=Stunt |first=W. T. |title=Turning the World Upside Down: A Century of Missionary Endeavour |location=Bath |publisher=Echos of Service |year=1973 |oclc=976643 |page=121 }}</ref>
==Biography==
Irvine was a superintendent of [[Belgaum]] Leprosy Hospital at Hindalga for 25 years.<ref>The Missionary review: Volume 49; Volume 49 1926 "Leper Bible Students - THE earnestness of the Christian lepers in an asylum in Belgaum, South India, is described as follows by William C. Irvine: "One Lord's Day morning, after the meeting, I told the Christians that I would take .."</ref><ref>Review: Twenty-five Years Work Among the Lepers of India. By William C. Irvine. 144 pp. Illus. 2s. 6rf. Pickering & Inglis. London. 1939. "The Superintendent of Belgaum Leper Hospital has given twenty-five years of service to the lepers of ..."</ref><ref>This spreading tree: the story of the Leprosy Mission from 1918 to ... , Leprosy Mission - 1974 "Mr. WC Irvine, of Belgaum, had to deal with an idea deeply embedded in the Hindu mind, and therefore difficult to eradicate. This is the concept of caste, that stratification of Hindu society in classes so rigidly bounded that none may .."</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Stunt |first=W. T. |title=Turning the World Upside Down: A Century of Missionary Endeavour |location=Bath |publisher=Echos of Service |year=1973 |oclc=976643 |page=233 }}</ref> He came to [[India]] from [[New Zealand]].<ref name="Stunt121" />
His best known work is ''Timely Warnings'' (1917), also known as ''Modern Heresies Exposed'' in its second edition and as ''Heresies Exposed'' subsequent to the 1921 edition.<ref>Encyclopedia of new religions: new religious movements, sects and ... Christopher Hugh Partridge - 2004 "Such opposition can be traced back to the early parts of the 20th century, when William C. Irvine published his ''Timely Warnings'' (1917), later reissued as ''Heresies Exposed'' (1955)."</ref> His books ''25 Years' Mission Work Among the Lepers of India'', ''Riches of the Gentiles'' and other works also received wide distribution.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Christian Faith and Life |volume=42 |year=1936 |page=173}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |journal=The Missionary Review of the World |volume=62 |year=1939 |publisher=Princeton Press |location=Princeton, New Jersey |page=112}}</ref> ''Heresies Exposed'' was one of the first widely available books to critically review [[new religious movement]]s such as [[Christian Science|Christian Scientists]], [[Jehovah's Witnesses]], [[Seventh-day Adventist Church|Seventh Day Adventists]], [[Two by Twos|Cooneyites]], [[Christadelphians]], [[Pentecostalism|Pentecostals]], [[Theosophical Society|Theosophists]] and other non-mainstream groups that came to increasing prominence during the 20th century.<ref>{{cite book |last=Irvine |first=William C. |title=Heresies Exposed |location=Neptune, New Jersey |publisher=Loizeaux Brothers |year=1985 | origyear=1917 |isbn=0-87213-401-6 }}</ref> It has seen multiple editions and printings, and remains in print today.<ref>The encyclopedic handbook of cults in America J. Gordon Melton - 1986 "In 1917, William C. Irvine published his ''Timely Warnings'', the first of the modern countercult books. ... Under its new title, ''Heresies Exposed'', Irvine's book went through twenty-nine printings by 1955 and remains in print in the 1980s."</ref>
==Publications==
*''Heresies Exposed'' 1st Edition 1917, (published as Timely Warnings), 2nd edition 1919 (published as Modern Heresies Exposed), 3rd edition 1921 (as Heresies Exposed), 4th edition 1923 (ditto), fifth edition 1927 (Rewritten and Enlarged), 6th edition 1929 (again enlarged), 7th edition 1930 (again enlarged), reprint 1932, 8th edition 1935 (Revised and Enlarged), 9th edition 1937, 10th edition 1935 (reprinted in USA), 11th edition 1941 (reprinted in India), 12th edition 1942 (reprinted in India), 1955, 1985 *''25 Years' Mission Work Among the Lepers of India'' (1938)
==See Also== [[Christian Apologetics]] [[Christian mission]] [[Algernon J. Pollock]]
